name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 25 October 2018.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, at the beginning of this sitting I would like to recall the centenary of the armistice, which ended the First World War in November 1918. On Saturday and Sunday I took part, on behalf of all of you, in the commemoration ceremonies held in Paris, in the presence of the leaders of the whole world.  History is a great teacher, but we do not always learn its lesson. It is therefore the duty of each of us to keep alive the memory of the millions of dead of the Great War. It is our task to preserve the historical memory of those events, reminding current and future generations that this immense tragedy, in which Europe committed its suicide, was the result of clashes, selfishness and confrontation between peoples. Twenty years later, unfortunately, nationalism once again led Europeans to fight each other. Today, one hundred years after the end of the First World War, we can see that the friendship and cooperation on which the European Union is founded makes a war between states unthinkable, but woe betide us to regard this state of affairs as irreversible.  The European project unites nations and guarantees peace, freedom and prosperity. It enables us to solve our problems through political debate and not on the battlefields. Let us defend this project and these ideals, not only for those who come after us, but also to pay tribute to the seventeen million who died in the First World War, whose sacrifice cannot have been in vain.  Finally, I would like to greet, with affection and pride, the many European nations born of this conflict, which this year celebrate the hundred years of their existence, including Poland, Romania, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia.  I would also like to express our condolences to the families of the dozens of victims caused by bad weather in Italy. In many regions, particularly in Valle d'Aosta, Veneto, Trentino, Liguria, Lazio, Campania and Sicily, weather conditions have caused the loss of numerous human lives and caused enormous damage to the economy, devastating many territories. The European Union stands ready to help the affected populations through the European Emergency Solidarity Fund. I would like to thank the European Commission for making civil protection available. I would also remind you that, thanks to the efforts of the European Parliament, it is possible to deal more quickly with requests for aid and to anticipate part of the funds requested.  The fact that many countries of the European Union are affected by devastating climatic events is, however, a warning sign for all of us. It is undeniable that these extreme weather events are the consequences of the wider problem of climate change. We must therefore redouble our efforts to combat it. The COP 24 meeting, to be held in Katowice, Poland, in December, gives us the opportunity to reaffirm European leadership in the fight against greenhouse gases and harmful emissions. I also welcome the ruling by the Supreme Court of Pakistan on the innocence of Asia Bibi, who was able to embrace his family again after eight years in prison. We are now a look forward to the conclusion of the judicial process and the ongoing review and we are confident that his acquittal will be definitively confirmed. I am in contact with Jan Fige and the Pakistani authorities to offer our support to the efforts to ensure the freedom and security of Asia Bibi and her loved ones.  (Applause)

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, when the European Commission presented its proposals for the so-called winter package in January 2016, it was clear that it had just started a long marathon of very demanding work. We have faced the challenge of achieving legislative proposals that are acceptable to both the European Parliament and the European Council, as well as to the European Commission, but at the same time allow european energy and climate change targets to be met. I believe that Europe not only has its long-term share of responsibility for the global environment, but also, unlike many others, has the means and potential to be the main architect of these changes.  I believe that it is no coincidence that today's debate on the clean energy package, and in fact the entire plenary session today, starts precisely with the Energy Efficiency Directive, because this is how we implement the 'energy efficiency first' rule in practice, and I believe that this trend will also be taken over by most Member States in the development of their energy policy.  On the other hand, at the beginning, we did not all share exactly the same view of how ambitious we should be in energy efficiency. Often, and it was because we otherwise interpreted the results of impact studies, or used other sources of mathematical models of the cost of energy efficiency measures, we differed greatly. But the European Parliament has always been one of the leaders when it comes to promoting an ambitious European climate policy. As elected representatives of the people of the European Union, we have full responsibility for finding the effective measures that, in my opinion, citizens expect of us.  We entered into negotiations with the Council in the spring with the call for a binding 30% energy efficiency target at the end of 2030, while the Council supported the 30% commission proposal in a non-binding format. We have had very long and technical discussions about the cost of the measures being implemented, their return and the impact on economic growth. I have always been and remain convinced, and I am supported by the results of impact studies and a number of analyses, that, despite the initial expenditure, these energy efficiency measures will have a very positive impact on economic growth, employment and on reducing the European Union's dependence on fossil fuel imports. I am glad that, after very difficult negotiations and many rounds of trilogues, we have managed to reach a compromise of 32.5%. I would, of course, like to see this figure higher, after all, I have clearly repeatedly supported the figure of 40% in the European Parliament, but let us bear in mind that 32.5% was a major concession to the Council.  There were also great discussions about the so-called Article Seven, where we ended up reaching a very good level of 0.8% of final energy consumption. This is very ambitious, more ambitious than the European Commission's original proposal. I would like to see, personally, the inclusion of transport in this article, which i did not succeed in at the end, but I believe that the Member States will behave responsibly in this regard. Finally, I would also like to mention the subject of energy poverty. As you know, our political group has long been a supporter of the idea of combating energy poverty on this ground. This has also made it possible to see recently that the problems of people who do not have the power to pay their heat or energy bills are more and more resonating among politicians at all levels. I am therefore extremely pleased, and I consider this a great success, that we have succeeded in significantly strengthening this aspect and motivating the Member States to prioritise investment in housing for the most vulnerable groups of the population in their savings planning.  The proposal for a directive will be revised in 2023, in the light of the implementation of climate agreements as well as progress in innovation and technology. We have agreed that we do not remain closed to higher ambitions, and I firmly believe in these higher ambitions. In the climate agreement, we are committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030, and increasing energy efficiency is the most economical way to do so. I believe that, by negotiating legislation on energy efficiency, we have indeed created a huge opportunity not only for our environment, but also for European industry, services and citizens, including the poorest groups, and for our competitiveness on the world market, which is increasingly under threat. I would therefore very much like the European Parliament to approve this agreement tomorrow by a large majority so that all our obligations under this directive are clear.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, I believe that the text we are going to vote on is a historic text because it is really a comprehensive project, which contains more than eight legislative proposals, including the proposal for a regulation on the governance of the energy union. In addition, it lays the groundwork for compatibility with the Paris Agreement and, in view of the latest report of the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change), it indicates that temperatures can rise to 1.5oC. This text is also a historic agreement because, for the first time, we are talking about a long-term strategy. The 2030 targets will then be set, which will have to be consistent with what we want to achieve in 2050. The governance text indicates that greenhouse gas emissions will be zero. This means that all the greenhouse gases we produce will have to be absorbed at the same time. It is really a goal that needs to be set. We often talk about 2050, but I think that at the level of the European Union, with the contribution of the developed countries, it would be nice if it were 2040. To do this, we must be consistent with the energy efficiency targets of 32.5% and those of renewable energy at 32%. It is true that these objectives are superior to those proposed by the Commission and the States. However, it will not be enough to reach 1.5oC because if you follow these goals, you can be above 2oC. In other words, the review in 2023 will be very important. It is also part of governance, with targets in 2022, 2025 and 2027. These steps are therefore essential if we are to be consistent with the Paris Agreements. It is also an innovative text at the level of governance because it ensures that, in the States, there are real debates and discussions with the various partners, that it is not always the executive that decides, that the different partners participate and that, at the same time, it is transparent. Because the Commission also needs civil society from the various Member States so that the objectives - since they are European objectives - can be achieved. So I think that both transparency and the internet platform will allow access to this data. But there is a downside: we need to be even more ambitious. For greenhouse gases, we have said 40%, but everyone knows that if we set ourselves targets for renewable energy and efficiency, we have to go up to 45%, and if the target is zero carbon in 2050, we have to go much further. We are even talking about 55% in 2030. Similarly, the Commission and the States agreed, we included the methane strategy, which was not included at all in the Commission's proposals. In this sense, it is an innovative text. But I have a question for the Commission, since it will have to present scenarios for the long-term strategy on 28 November. I would therefore like to ask Mr Caete what is the status of the Commission on this long-term strategy and, above all, I would like to say to him that it must propose scenarios at 1.5oC, as the IPCC Group is asking, precisely so that we are- and my colleague said earlier - ambitious about the positioning of the European Union vis-à-vis the rest of the world.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent The regulation on the governance of the EU Energy Union and on climate action is one of the most important regulations that we have been able to deliver in energy and climate policy during this parliamentary term. For the first time, we are getting a coherent and collecting tool to bring about climate policy. We would never have come here without skilled colleagues from the Green Group. In particular, I would like to highlight the great work of Mrs Rivasi and Mr Turmes on this legislation, but not to belittle, also my colleagues from the other political groups who, together with the Commission and the Council of Ministers, have shown great willingness to compromise. We often think differently, not least in climate policy, but because of the very urgent situation, I am very pleased that we have been able to come together, agree and show common willingness to compromise. Because we can no longer afford to be passive. We can no longer push the deeper green transition into the future. The consequences of climate change are becoming increasingly obvious, and we are seeing how it will become increasingly expensive and increasingly painful if we do not act. In Sweden this summer was the warmest in a very long time. We had serious forest fires throughout the country, and had not been in favour of the rescue we received from our European colleagues, the situation would have been very problematic. Now we also see how it burns in California. The situation is increasingly acute in more and more countries. In recent weeks, we have received reports from the IPCC on how far we have left to be in line with our climate targets. That is why this regulation is so important. It is a road map for us to achieve the Paris Agreement. We see how a clear climate policy framework to get all the way to Paris is now beginning to take shape when we finally get to a zero emissions target. We have a call for all countries to develop national energy and climate plans and for a mechanism to be put in place to identify when our actions are not in line with our objectives, so that we can correct the course with a firm target against Paris. This regulation also creates long-term rules for Europe's businesses and industries. European companies need to know what is at stake, what strategies, what technologies European countries will invest in, so that they know that the investments they make in new and green technologies will be profitable. In this legislation, we also see how, for the first time, the EU is starting to work on CO2 budgets. This is an important and historic step in order for us to have a scientifically robust climate policy. The climate will not be saved by beautiful speeches, but by scientifically based policies and carbon records. This regulation is a first significant step towards the Union taking responsibility on climate change. With this roadmap, we are now laying the foundations for a future climate policy framework that ensures that the EU does its part to achieve the objectives of the Paris Agreement.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, today we can say that Europe is responding to the challenge of climate change.  The agreement reached in June on the Directive on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources is a great agreement. For multiple reasons: Firstly, because we are going to double the current rate of renewable energy and go further, I have no doubt, in the 2023 review; because we increase legal certainty and simplify administrative procedures, which are crucial to ensuring investment; or because we raise the share of renewables in highly polluting sectors, such as heating, cooling or transport.  But there is a unique element to this directive which I would like to highlight.  Europe is often accused of being away, of not being in tune and of not listening to citizens, and today we can proudly say that Europe has not only listened to them but has placed them at the heart of energy policy.  We have done so by enshrining for the first time the right to self-consumption, i.e. the right to produce, the right to consume, the right to store and the right to sell the surplus of the energy produced.  We have done this by betting on extending the benefits of renewables to the most vulnerable citizens, contributing to the fight against energy poverty.  And we have done so by pushing for fair energy transition measures so that those territories where the weight of coal was very important can have a fair transition process, that they understand that no one abandons them to their fate.  The commitment to renewables is a commitment to innovation, it is a commitment to economic activity, it is a commitment to quality employment in a sector where Europe lays the foundation for regaining global leadership, and is a commitment to our own energy sources to be more energy independent.  Yes, one of the pillars of the Energy Union is precisely to strengthen our energy independence. Hence the path we open with this directive.  More importantly, this agreement which we have reached, together with the efficiency agreement, will allow us to be much more ambitious, Commissioner, in the decarbonisation targets set by the European Union by 40% by 2030. We can go further, we can review it and we can reach 45%.  Europe must be ambitious and therefore raise its commitments at the next Climate Summit by giving a leadership signal and giving, above all, a sign of commitment to the world, especially once the United States has abandoned the Paris Agreement.  And if these achievements have been possible, it has been because of the climate of mutual trust, the teamwork and commitment of parliament's entire negotiating team and also the commitment of the Commission and, very uniquely, the shadow rapporteurs of Kelly, Federley, Tamburrano, Henkel, Paloma and Turmes, as well as colleagues from the Committee on the Environment , captained by Bas.  The European Union's motto is "United in Diversity". Several were our views, but we have been able to move forward together to achieve our goals. Undoubtedly, there has been our strength and the key to success.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is a real pleasure to be here today to discuss three files which are central for the Clean Energy for All Europeans package. I would like to take this opportunity in plenary to thank you all for the role that the European Parliament delegation played in June in securing a political agreement. My special thanks go to the four rapporteurs: José Blanco López, Miroslav Poche, Michèle Rivasi and Claude Turmes, and also Jakop Dalunde. I would of course also like to thank President Jerzy Buzek and Adina-Ioana Vălean, and all the shadow rapporteurs involved. Without them we would not have got such an ambitious package. At the beginning of next month the COP 24 meets in Katowice, where we are aiming for a successful outcome to agree on the detailed rules for the implementation of the Paris Agreement. The European Union needs to assert its leadership and, by giving the files under the Clean Energy Package its strong support, this Parliament can play an important role in making this happen. Closing these files strengthens the European Union position as one of the most active leaders in the energy transition process and helps raise our collective ambition. These are perhaps the three most important dossiers in terms of delivering tangible benefits because of the targets contained in these new rules. They will set a stable and predictable legal framework for the way forward and enable us to make this major transformation for the economy and society – the clean energy transition. Let me now say a few words about the three different dossiers, starting with energy efficiency. The key element in the agreement is that it sets a new headline energy efficiency target for the European Union for 2030 of at least 32.5%, with an upward revision clause by 2023. Thanks to the European Parliament, we now have an ambitious outcome for 2030. The changes will also extend the current annual energy-saving obligation beyond 2020. This is a measure that has been a key driver in the progress made in recent years. Taken together, these targets are vital as they will attract private investment and support the emergence of new market actors. This will also help drive research and innovation towards finding new solutions. ‘Energy efficiency first’ is a key principle of our energy policy. It is an area where ambition pays off in terms of benefits for reinforced security of supply, improved competitiveness of our industries, GDP growth, and increased employment. The agreed text includes a number of tangible benefits for consumers, such as possible savings on their energy bills, improved living conditions and improved air quality. Furthermore, consumer rights on billing and individual metering will be strengthened. The new rules will make household bills more transparent to ensure that they are more understandable. Last but not least, energy efficiency measures also represent an important instrument for alleviating energy poverty. Let me turn now to the Renewable Energy Directive. Here again the position of the Parliament delegation was instrumental in securing a higher target for 2030. The text foresees a new binding renewable energy target for the European Union for 2030 of at least 32%. It also includes a review clause by 2023 for an upward revision of the European Union-level target. This is considerably higher than the 27% target originally outlined two years ago. In broader terms, the revised directive further ‘Europeanises’ our approach to renewable energy, creating conditions for a cost—efficient deployment of renewables across the European Union. It introduces the principle of non—retroactivity for support provided, improves the design of support schemes for renewables to make it more market-oriented, and it streamlines the administrative procedures. For consumers, it establishes a clear and stable regulatory framework on self—consumption – for the first time in European Union legislation – which I believe will encourage more and more households to become actively involved in the clean energy transition as consumers. On the design and support schemes and the scope of tendering, the Commission would like to reiterate, though, that while fully supporting the objectives of the Directive, the Commission considers that they could be achieved without the respective wording of Article 4. This declaration has been transmitted to the European Parliament and will be annexed to the minutes. That brings me to the third and final file, the new Governance Regulation. While the revisions of the two directives will provide further impetus for investment in renewables and energy efficiency – the two major elements contributing to reducing greenhouse gas emissions – the Governance Regulation establishes the process, ensuring Member States achieve this in a coherent and the most efficient way possible across all dimensions of the Energy Union. It complements the European Union ETS Directive, the Efforts Sharing and LULUCF regulations, and provides genuine European added value. The new regulation requires each Member State to prepare an integrated national energy and climate plan for a 10-year period, starting with 2021 to 2030. This unique tool will allow assessing progress in achieving the Energy Union and our targets as it will, for the first time, encompass all relevant policies and measures of Member States and the results of regional cooperation. The Commission may then make recommendations on the plans aimed at ensuring, in case of deviations, that the European Union meets the 2030 energy and climate targets in the most coherent, collaborative and cost—effective way. The European Parliament and the Council will address, on an annual basis, progress achieved in the Energy Union in all dimensions of energy and climate policy. I must underline that the rules fully respect Member States’ choices in determining their own energy mix. But it brings a fair and robust mechanism to facilitate the collective attainment of the binding European Union renewables target, the European Union energy efficiency target and the 15% interconnection target, while also considering research, innovation and competitiveness. For the sake of completeness, let me recall two declarations made by the Commission during the negotiations: our commitment to analyse methane emissions, while at the same time preserving our right of initiative; and on the importance of a clear division of competences within the future two committees assisting the Commission in the implementation of the regulation, which we would have preferred to be in one single committee. These declarations are transmitted to the European Parliament and will be annexed to the minutes. The adoption of these three dossiers will mean that we will have finalised half of the Clean Energy for All Europeans package and set our main energy-related targets for 2030. The fact that the targets agreed are higher than those originally proposed by the Commission means that we can probably achieve even steeper emission reductions by 2030. Our latest modelling suggests that meeting these targets will de facto enable a reduction of emissions of roughly 45% across the European Union by 2030, going beyond the 40% Paris Agreement commitment. This will allow the European Union to show true leadership with real action in next month’s COP 24 talks in Katowice. We are making progress on the other clean energy dossiers – regarding electricity market design, including risk preparedness – and I am optimistic that, with the same ambition and constructive approach from all sides that we have shown on these files, we can conclude these before the end of the year under the Austrian Council Presidency. Taken together with other parts of the package, I am convinced that these changes will have a positive impact on our quality of life and ultimately lead to cheaper household energy bills. Similarly, negotiations on the low—carbon mobility package are advancing and we hope to conclude the files under this Parliament. You will also be aware that the Commission concept for the next Multiannual Financial Framework will put climate—related spending at the heart of our budget. As well as raising the ambition for climate, including clean energy transition mainstreaming across all European Union programmes from 20% to at least 25% from 2021 onwards, we are looking to boost the level of spending in all the main budget areas, notably research and structural investment. One of the main legacies of this Commission and this Parliament will be that we have put climate change and clean energy transition at the heart of our agenda. This is what we need to explain to our citizens, especially in the run—up to the next European elections, where you can be proud of the important progress achieved together. I look forward to the debate. Statements by the Commission (in writing) Proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources (recast) “The Commission notes that both Co-Legislators have agreed on Article 4 with the content going beyond the general principles of the Commission proposal COM(2016) 767 final. While fully supporting the objectives of the Directive, the Commission considers that they could be achieved without the agreed wording of paragraphs 3 (third sub-paragraph), 4 (second and third sub-paragraphs), 5 and 6 of Article 4, as demonstrated by the currently applicable Directive 2009/28/EC.” Proposal for a Regulation of the European parliament and of the Council on the Governance of the Energy Union amending Directive 94/22/EC, Directive 98/70/EC, Directive 2009/31/EC, Regulation (EC) No 663/2009, Regulation (EC) No 715/2009, Directive 2009/73/EC, Council Directive 2009/119/EC, Directive 2010/31/EU, Directive 2012/27/EU, Directive 2013/30/EU and Council Directive (EU) 2015/652 and repealing Regulation (EU) No 525/2013 Commission Statement on methane on Article 16 The Commission notes the agreement of the co-legislators relating to Article 16 by which a strategic plan should be presented for methane. The Commission confirms its commitment to analyse methane emissions, notably in the context of the Union's long-term strategy. The Commission emphasizes however that it reserves the right to respond in accordance with the rules of the Treaty, with due regard in particular to its right of initiative. Commission Statement on Article 44 The Regulation on the Governance of the Energy Union is central to the Clean Energy for All Europeans Package. This Regulation aims to set out the process ensuring the ambition and coherence of policies and measures which are taken at various levels for the achievement of the Energy Union objectives and, in particular, the 2030 EU climate and energy targets. In their Joint Declaration on the EU's legislative priorities for 2018 - 2019, the three Institutions committed to delivering on the objective of an ambitious Energy Union with a forward-looking climate change policy, notably by implementing the 2030 EU climate and energy framework, by continuing to follow up the Paris Agreement, including through legislation on clean energy for all Europeans. Against this background, the Commission notes the agreement of the co-legislators relating to Article 44, which provides that the Commission shall be assisted by two committees in the implementation of the Regulation. The Commission regrets that the co-legislators could not accept the Commission proposal that the exercise of implementing powers conferred on the Commission should be under the control of a single committee, in full compliance with the applicable comitology rules set forth in Regulation 182/2011 and in view of streamlining and Better Regulation. The Commission reiterates the importance of a clear division of competences between the committees which is essential for a proper exercise of the Commission's implementing powers and the application of Regulation 182/2011 establishing horizontal rules applicable to committees.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: draftser of the Opinion of the Committee on Development. – Madam President, UN experts are very expensive. To avoid the tremendous consequences of climate change and take advantage of the enormous economic, social and ecological benefits of complying with the Paris climate agreement, we must be realistic, that is, ambitious. That is, to reduce our emissions by 55% by 2030, as proposed by this House, and to achieve zero net emissions by 2040. Any long-term strategy of the European Commission must be compatible with limiting global warming to 1.5oC.  COP 24 is only one month away, and Europe has the capacity and responsibility to lead global climate ambition. And for this, the potential of citizen energy is fundamental. Let us make Europeans the real protagonists of the energy revolution, betting on a model that is democratic, just, sustainable and decentralized. That's the way, Commissioner.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This week, Europe is taking further steps towards a more efficient and climate-smart society. All the calculations show that the more energy we save, the better for society, the climate, human health, our energy security. In addition, we are creating new jobs and growth as we now invest in a more efficient use of energy. It's a real win-win-win. As the committee's chief negotiator, I have participated throughout the process. I was, of course, particularly pleased to have the ambition of 40% energy savings in the Environment Committee by 2030. Unfortunately, I have seen some watering down of that position and can see that we did not quite come all the way. However, we still managed to achieve many good decisions, and I would like to thank the rapporteur for very good cooperation. With a target of 32.5% more energy efficiency by 2030, hundreds of thousands of new jobs will be created in Europe while climate emissions will be reduced, our fossil fuel imports will decrease and health will improve. Thanks to this, we are doing a lot of win-win for Europe.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Madam President, first I would like to point out that what we are going to adopt tomorrow is going to be a historic package for 2030. An energy package that is stimulating on efficiency, renewables and also making sure that we have a governance in place, that it’s not only numbers on paper but that we are really going to deliver. I think it cannot be stressed enough that it was really Parliament, at the core, that raised the ambitions on all these files. The Commission was probably forced by the Member States to come up with a proposal that was written some time in 2014, but I have to say that the Commission, during the negotiations, was helpful and realised that it could step up. It was helpful also in indicating that the numbers that were being used were outdated and that therefore we could do more on efficiency and renewables, which we are all celebrating here today. But it was really Parliament that played a crucial role in achieving that. In the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), we were very much focusing on issues surrounding biofuels and biomass. I think it is good to realise that, for the first time ever, we have sustainability criteria in place for biomass use in, for example, power plants. However, that was another big fight, especially with the forestry countries who do want to sell their biomass all over Europe but do not want any European regulation. We are taking the first steps now, but you will see that more will be needed to make sure that we’re not just burning trees in coal-fired power plants in the future, which is still a concern for citizens. On biofuel specifically, I think the market signal is very clear: we are moving away from food—based crops and we are moving towards advanced biofuels. That market signal is very clear and it was also an achievement of Parliament to make sure that the caps we put in place make sense. However, there is still one big discussion and that’s specifically on palm oil. We managed in the end, and Parliament was very clear: we want to phase out palm oil. We have now agreed on delegated acts with a deadline of the beginning of next year, but we hear some concerns that forces in the Commission are a bit doubtful about really making a strong proposal on that. Let me be very clear: if the Commission is not going to deliver on this, the debate on biofuels will continue forever. It’s in your interest to make sure that this system can work, but then you have to be credible on limiting the worst biofuels, palm oil in particular. We will be watching closely.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Mr President, Commissioner, climate scientists around the world conclude that if we are to avoid the worst effects of climate change, we must not allow the earth to warm up beyond one and a half degrees. But individual countries cannot do this alone, so European cooperation is sorely needed. I am therefore pleased that the EU now has ambitious plans to save energy and to use renewable energy. Only it should not become an end in itself. It is about reducing CO2 emissions, and I also believe that we need to look seriously at the use of nuclear energy. What I am very pleased about is that this legislation has tightened up the criteria for biofuel. Because, of course, we cannot use biofuels that have higher CO2 emissions than, for example, fossil fuels, and that this will lead to a collision in the production of these biofuels.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Dear Chairman, with the adoption of the Energy Package of Laws, the European Union will continue to build its future based on sustainability, environmental care, adaptation to climate change and sustainable resource management. The European Union also makes sure that citizens' money is not wasted unnecessarily on energy imports if we can use this money at home, for example to create new jobs in the bioeconomy or energy efficiency.  The Renewable Energy Promotion Directive set an ambitious but achievable target of at least 32 % of the share of renewable energy in gross consumption by 2030.  We, on the AGRI board, dealt with the most issues of biofuels and biomass. Conventional biofuels will continue to play their role in decarbonising the transport sector, while promoting in particular the deployment of advanced biofuels and greater use of renewable electricity.  Member States rich in forest biomass will continue to be able to use this important natural and renewable resource, respecting sustainability criteria based on risk assessment.  I would like to thank all my colleagues on the AGRI board for their support.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, hundreds of petitions from European citizens have helped to update the very important directive on the promotion of renewable energies and I, as draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions, am honoured to have brought their voice.  Petitions have revealed shortcomings and critical issues, including systematic, both in the existing legal framework and in its practical application in the Member States, as in particular in the case mentioned of retroactive changes to support systems. This new directive strictly prohibits this practice, precisely in order to prevent those who wish to invest in renewable energy from having to fear that their investment could be jeopardised precisely by retroactive rules that undermine the economic stability of projects.  Those provisions for The Member States on the publication of a long-term plan for support mechanisms, covering a period of at least five years, are therefore also a good thing, so as to improve the clarity and security of investment in this sector. The Committee on Petitions had been a little more ambitious, however, with regard to the EU renewable energy target. We were asking for 35 % and, nevertheless, the 32 % achieved in the final agreement is a very good step forward compared to the European Commission's initial proposal, especially as it is safeguarded by an upward revision to 2023. Europe finally comes close to its citizens when it writes rules like this on renewables, because promoting the use and self-consumption of renewable energy means increasing the degree of democracy in our society, it means taking concrete action to protect the planet from global warming, it means creating jobs in the green economy, it means tackling the problem of energy poverty, which today still affects fifty million people throughout the European Union. , and above all it means working in practice to try to leave a future for future generations, because unfortunately until now this Europe has been heading in the opposite direction. So let's move forward with the energy revolution.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, praise and thanks to the Commission: this Clean Energy package is really well coordinated, from energy savings to the expansion of renewables to governance and also the references to emissions trading. This has not always been the case in European legislation, particularly in energy legislation. But then I would also like to praise us – self-praise. I believe that Parliament has achieved a more intensive energy transition at important points, but without exaggerating it. Member States and regions have room to contribute their very specific strengths to energy production and also to energy saving. In this way, we achieve the environmental and climate targets without driving out the industry and without overburdening our cities and communities. However, these were very narrow decisions in Parliament. The left side - red, green, yellow - wanted to save 40% energy. This would have slowed structural change to renewables, and would have overwhelmed urban and municipal redevelopment quotas for public buildings. 3% refurbishment rate, that would have been 2 billion euros a year for a federal state in Germany, North Rhine-Westphalia. Savings, commitment, commitment, regulation – these are the favourite words of the left, the Greens and many populists, including here in the House. But climate protection is also creative. But every region must be able to contribute what it does best. Flexibility and security of supply are therefore required instead of paternalism. Since 1990, European national product has increased by 55%, and over the same period emissions have fallen by 25%. We want to continue along this path with pleasure in terms of environmental protection and in terms of jobs.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, as has been mentioned, tomorrow we will be voting on three very important reports on the Clean Energy Package. This package represents the most important work done in the field of energy in this term, and it defines the way forward for our energy landscape for the next decade. It has been a tough battle for Parliament to succeed, as we all know and as has been mentioned, on the energy efficiency and the renewable goals. In the first reading in this Parliament we asked for 35% for both. We were not able to maintain that, but we can be proud of this result as we had to overcome the resistance of the Council and, unfortunately, also a rather weak basis to work on from the Commission. This again is proof that this Parliament is of utmost importance to keep ambitions very high, and in that sense the regulation on governance is very important, especially given the absence of national binding targets on energy efficiency and renewable energy. The Governance Regulation provides the Commission with the tool to integrate and evaluate the National Energy and Climate Plan. Each Member State has to come forward by the end of this year. If the sum of the pledges in these plans do not add up to the Union’s collective goals, the Commission can make a Member State step up that ambition. It is extremely important to step them up because, as we know, the proposals that are in front of us are a first step but are not enough to meet our climate objectives to keep the temperature well below the 2 degrees – and, you know, that should be 1.5 degrees. This package deals with the goals towards the 2030 targets, and in that context of climate and energy targets, that means tomorrow. Therefore, however important, this is not an end, and this is not a stop. These reports are a crucial step of many to come. Reaching our climate and energy goals, as well as each of the SDGs, in a socially just manner, is the top priority of the S&D Group, and we shall put these challenges not just here, but in all the files that we negotiate: for instance, the Multiannual Financial Framework is the next step to come. We are also looking to the long-term Decarbonisation Strategy for 2050, Mr Commissioner. We expect the Commission to take into account the most recent developments and challenges ahead of us – like, for instance, the again alarming results of the IPCC report and Parliament’s request stated in the resolution on COP24. The last but very crucial point for our Group is the requirement of combating energy poverty that we managed to get into the energy efficiency and into the government’s report. It’s the first time – and very important – that very specific obligations aimed at people living in energy poverty have been enshrined in European legislation. And that, I can say, is a true victory for my political group.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will take a major step towards more renewable energy and more energy efficiency in the European Union. We have negotiated this legislation long and hard and it is now time to make decisions. I count on overwhelming support in Parliament for this. Everyone has had to put water on the wine, including myself as a shadow rapporteur. It is clear that we all want to achieve the Paris objectives, but we must not forget that we must also bring our citizens along, because it is they, our citizens and our businesses, who will pay for all these measures. In countries where the flight has been taken, such as in Germany with the Energiewende, we see that in the first decades the hoped-for results will not be achieved for the environment, unless we want to saddle the Germans with a sky-high bill. So we have to be ambitious, but we have to be realistic. We also need to continue to convince our trading partners to participate in an eco-realistic narrative. The EU accounts for just 10% of global emissions. So we must not compete with ourselves and we must also advocate the green revolution in other parts of the world.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: for the ALDE Group. Madam President! Three years ago, Europe's leaders shook hands on an ambitious climate agreement in Paris. Hand-strikes to take the lead in the climate fight. But it can sometimes seem that these very same governments have been affected by what might be called acute green amnesia. They promised us gold and green forests at the Paris toasters, but at the negotiating tables in Brussels, there could suddenly be a long way to go. This also applies to my own government in Denmark, which used to be even more ambitious in the green field.  Just look at the new renewable energy and energy efficiency targets that we are going to vote on this week. This is an obvious opportunity to raise green ambitions. Obviously because we know that climate change poses a greater threat than ever before. And obviously because we know that the price of solar and wind energy is falling year after year. Obviously because we have to be independent of Putin in the east and the sheikhs of the Middle East. It is good that we could at least make some agreements and congratulations to all the rapporteurs who have been involved, but we are not ambitious enough on behalf of the climate. We need to be even more ambitious, because otherwise we will lose the fight against climate change that is taking place at the moment. We are the first generation to experience these climate change, and we are the last to do anything real and effective to limit them. That is why our governments must keep what they have helped to promise in Paris, and if they forget, then we in the European Parliament must be more than ready and willing to help them along the way, just as we have done through all the negotiations we have been through here.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I am really happy that, after lengthy discussions, common sense won over short-sighted interests and the co-legislators set a 2030 headline target of 32.5% for the Energy Efficiency Directive to be implemented across sectors. However, we cannot sit back and relax. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report clearly points out that we have to do much more than we are doing already, and we should increase our ambition. Let me remind you that the Greens/EFA Group in the European Parliament have asked for a binding 40% target, in line with the Paris Agreement objective and in line with the needs, according to the IPCC report. Some colleagues are referring to realism and reality. But let me clarify that there is no stronger reality in the future than climate change. We can do nothing with our economic growth or industrial activity if the climate collapses. There is a huge difference between the 1.5° or the 2° climate change, and that depends on our ambition in the Energy Efficiency Directive and the Renewables Directive. This depends on this Clean Energy Package. I have to emphasise also that it’s not only about climate change and the environment. A higher ambition is a strong policy signal leading to more business actors to come on board for the energy transition. It means consumers living in decent homes, saving on their energy bills, and hundreds of thousands of jobs created in the green industries – up to 900 000 jobs according to the European Commission. Finally, let me emphasise also that this is the way to lift out millions of European citizens from energy poverty.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's clean energy package has been eagerly awaited. Hopefully, we will also be able to achieve these common objectives at Member State level. Votes are not enough in this House alone, but concrete action is expected from the Member States. For example, guidelines have now been issued for the use of renewable energy for the next 12 years. The guidelines could, of course, have been even more ambitious, because our climate continues to warm and the IPCC report was certainly nothing to read. It is sad to see that we continue to pit jobs and climate and environmental work against each other without realising that a real green revolution is being created by creating new ways of producing energy, creating new ways of doing things and also being able to market them to the world. Hardly any country wants to be destroying the environment, the climate, our planet any longer. There may have been moments of disappointment, but I have to say that now the overall package is one that I personally can personally support. Because the situation is at least improving in relation to today's everyday real situations in the Member States.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we began this process in the revision of European energy legislation at the beginning of this parliamentary term. The Commission's first proposal is even 28 May 2014. So, this work has marked the work of me and all my colleagues in recent years. I have to say, as a citizen who has joined the institutions, that I feel particularly proud to have worked together with some fantastic colleagues, which have certainly led to results that I myself never imagined. I dreamed that the rights of producers and consumers of renewable energy would finally be established, that there was a European right in Europe to set up energy communities, it was a dream that I had as a citizen, and here in this House, together with my fellow Members, I found people who wanted the same thing and we managed to make it European law. This should be the Europe of the future, we are writing it here, because we are finally focusing on something real: energy, matter, the circular economy. Then the European Union was born as a Coal and Steel Community and we are somehow going back to basics, focusing on energy, no longer on coal but on a new form of energy and a new form of material management that is no longer that of simple production of steel and manufactured goods. This should be the Europe of the future. There is a lot of talk about sovereignty, about nationalism. So I dream of a sovereign European Union, not broken up into individual states, where everyone wants to do what they want, because if we are to tackle climate change and the depletion of resources, we must build a strong Europe. I have seen in the negotiations that all the advantages, let us say the ambitious things that we in Parliament had written, even supported by the Commission, were hampered by the desire and particular interest of some States. So what does sovereignty mean? It means that we must move towards a different Europe in order to combat climate change and resource depletion, and together we can do it. This is our future.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, if the fight against climate change is necessary, it is a pity that this noble cause is being misguided. In the context of the energy union, the energy transition becomes a pretext for the European Commission taking power over energy issues. Energy is essential to the operation of our businesses, to the lives of individuals or to travel, and energy is, by its very nature, one of the main strategic policies of a state. National sovereignty in this area is, for our political family, non-negotiable.  The energy efficiency objectives are in the direction of the common interest and an effective fight against energy waste, they are one of the few positive points of the texts discussed today. Conversely, interconnection objectives should continue to be a matter of free cooperation between states. However, they will be subject to the wishes of the Commission, which intends to organise the interdependence of free nations. Similarly, binding renewable energy targets are a serious attack on national sovereignty. In the case of France, they do not take into account the strong presence of decarbonised nuclear energy in our energy mix. With intermittent energies requiring fossil fuels to compensate for their variations in production, we risk arriving at the paradox of an increase in CO2 emissions.  Governance also requires Member States to submit national energy and climate plans. It also allows the Commission to obtain binding powers over the strategic choices of energy mixes. A Member State that does not follow the direction of your technocrats should explain itself publicly and would be subject to sanctions. We have already said this in this Chamber and we will say it again, this is not the Europe we want. Finally, beyond this energy union, it should be noted that the fight against massive pollution due to excessive free trade and the resulting transport is never mentioned. It is true that a proactive policy in this area would call into question your ultraliberal dogma. However, this is a fight for the future against one of the main sources of CO2 emissions.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The way in which we are trying to combat this serious problem – because global warming, man-made climate change and environmental pollution is a problem – is, as always, inappropriate. Firstly, we do not maintain technological neutrality, we are clearly trying to push certain technologies at the expense of other technologies, sometimes for unclear reasons and without sufficient knowledge in this direction. We should aim to create mechanisms that are evenly charged to all users of the environment with some kind of fee, and the technologies they will develop to avoid these fees are already theirs, we cannot impose these technologies on them. More besides, the belief that by limiting the participation of Europe, which is still only responsible for 10% of global emissions, will save the planet's climate, is wrong, and relying on erroneous dreams leads to bad rules and discouraging others, because everyone sees that the energy-intensive industry is fleeing Europe elsewhere, and by observing this, they will not want to follow in our footsteps. Raising these rates from 30% to 50% is all the more not conducive to this. It's all the wrong way to go and it's ill-thought out.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the conclusion of the negotiations of this trilogue which have led to a balanced agreement between Parliament and the Council. We have indeed agreed on a reasonable and reasoned path, which echoes our group's vision in the negotiations, namely ambitious but realistic environmental objectives, which are in line with the Paris agreement. Building an energy Europe means encouraging all players to reduce their energy consumption, but it also accompanies them towards more sustainable consumption. Therefore, the protection of the environment and the competitiveness of companies must go hand in hand and the objectives set out in this text open up opportunities that will enable both private and public actors to invent the solutions of tomorrow. But building europe of energy also means guaranteeing our independence and allowing us to be competitive in the global concert. I have been advocating for many years for the development of protein crops for animal feed on our continent, in order to reduce our dependence on imports of GMO products or those from deforestation. That is why I will be following the preparations for the delegated acts very closely, particularly with regard to biofuels. These future decisions are of great importance for the future of The European agricultural sectors.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: – Madam President, I am very proud to have been part of this Clean Energy Package: incredibly important legislation that will affect all European citizens. We were able to demonstrate clear progressive leadership on all three files. It commits the European Union to renewable energy and energy efficiency targets in line with the Paris Agreement, of at least 32% and 32.5%. The UK must remain part of this legislation. Our work means we’ll be able to integrate renewables further into our energy mix as well as phase out high-polluting biofuels and increase industry’s investment in innovative technologies while supporting self-generation among consumers and local renewable-energy communities. Energy efficiency is a fundamental part of the sustainable transition and is central to achieving our Paris goals. It is crucial for the competitiveness of our industries, for future growth and job creation. Improved energy efficiency targets will secure a better quality of life for those in energy poverty. For every 1% improvement in energy efficiency, three million homes can be properly renovated and seven million people lifted out of energy poverty. Significantly, these targets must apply not only across the EU but in the United Kingdom. The need for the UK to meet our climate change commitments cannot and must not be a victim of Brexit. The targets must be seen as a bare minimum, not as aspirational. The UK must commit to meeting these targets as part of the Brexit negotiations and to staying an active member of the Internal Energy Market, for the sake of our planet and our children’s future. So I urge this Chamber: what we need now is implementation, and we need Member States to fulfil their targets and promises. We can no longer delay action, and Europe needs to be a real world leader in combating climate change. In Brexit, I urge the UK to take its climate change responsibilities seriously and to do the same.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I am glad that, in my opinion, the objectives of significant changes have been too ambitious during the trilogue. I would particularly highlight energy efficiency. Here, adopting the originally programmed targets would mean incredibly high investment costs and huge price fluctuations. I am also glad that we have managed to relax the obligations arising from the so-called 'Governance' and to keep the package as much as possible in the field of energy: that is what 'Governance' is all about. There is not such an excessive shift to climate.  Ensuring the safety and reliability of the electricity supply remains essential for me, under the responsibility of the Member States. Competences and decision-making powers relating to the security and reliability of electricity supply must therefore also remain essential at Member State level. The role of regional or European organisations and their acts must remain only recommending, without decision-making powers. The same applies to the energy mix. Only a Member State must retain the right to choose the energy mix and, at the same time, the ability to benefit from it. It also means the obligation to bear the disadvantages of this choice. A Member State may not be obliged, but only the possibility, to bear in solidarity the costs arising from the choice of energy mixes in the neighbouring Member States.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for These are, as I have said, historic decisions that we are now taking, as many colleagues here have pointed out. We are laying the foundations for improving energy security within the Union, where we do not depend on third countries outside the Union. We are taking clear steps towards meeting the objectives we have set us through the Paris Agreement. But is this enough? I dare say that it really isn't. That is why, both in this and other environmental and climate legislation, such as the ETS regulation, we have included a review clause which means that, after we have carried out the major review of the Paris Agreement in 2023, we are also reviewing our own legislation to see if it is strong enough. I am particularly pleased to have been involved in negotiating the renewable energy package, which is extremely important not only for completing the energy transition, but also for jobs across the European Union. It is with regret, however, that I have heard colleagues here today stand and spread a lie that is not true that we who come from countries with a lot of forest only want to export biomass to those who have a great deal of coal. That's not true! What we want to do with our forest is to make sure that we produce productive things from the fiber and do not burn the forest.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, just over 65 years ago, the European Union created its first institution: the European Coal and Steel Community. Of course, the challenges have changed: it is no longer a question of making peace within the European Union but, ultimately, of making peace with our future, of making peace with the environment and then, of course, of building an economy and creating jobs within the European Union. To say the least, the European Commission and the Member States have not had the courage of our founding fathers in the face of these challenges. The European Parliament has been more ambitious, but 32% is not yet up to what we need to do or what we can do. But I'm optimistic because I'm a realist. Renewable energy represents economic and industrial rationality if we know how to protect our industries, especially from Chinese competition. First of all, they reflect the economic reality, of course. Renewable energy has a cost that has been halved in ten years for wind power, seven for photovoltaics while the cost of nuclear power has tripled. Renewable energy obviously represents social rationality. One million jobs are created worldwide each year around renewable energy, that's two to three times more jobs per unit of production than fossil fuels or nuclear energy. Renewable energy is also synonymous with rationality in the development of our territories. How many of our territories today are marked by job losses, economic losses, business losses? Let us invest in our territories with the energy transition, this is geopolitical rationality, this is the rationality of citizens. Finally, we allow citizen communities access to renewable energy. But we have to show geopolitical rationality, democratic rationality, because, frankly, depending on water, wind and sea is still nicer than relying on Putin or the petromonarchies of the Gulf or Gabon.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, there is no denying the positive aspects of the Directive on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources in respect of renewable energy communities, self-consumption and support measures, among others.  Unfortunately, the rest of the package — efficiency and governance — has not had the same result and therefore the whole will be insufficient to meet the objectives set out in the Paris Agreement and to stop the serious consequences of climate change.  The Council was below the ambitions that European citizens are demanding, especially with regard to transport, the use of biofuels and the lack of binding country targets. We need more ambition to respond to the demands for the preservation of life on the planet, because this is precisely what we are talking about.  Once again, some countries have placed the short-term interests of multinationals above the general interests of companies. In the current scenario, the rise of the far right in countries such as Brazil or the United States adds more concerns in this area. The authoritarian agenda sees the defence of the environment as an enemy to beat and nature, a resource that can be sheared.  We have little time to reverse this situation, and renewable energy is a part of the solution in a fair energy transition process. But it's not enough.  Let us not miss the opportunity: we are playing the future, and the European Union can and must face this challenge.

name: Julia REID
text: – Madam President, we are all aware of the catastrophic consequences that pollution has for our health and the environment. It’s been estimated that 43% of deaths globally are caused by environmental air pollution and, if this is true, it is costing billions of euros a year. It should be our right as human beings to breathe fresh air and live in a clean environment. Member States should actively monitor the activities of big polluters in their countries and take ad hoc measures to reduce pollution levels. However, regarding the EU’s clean energy package, I believe the Commission should not interfere with Member States’ plans to reduce pollution. The EU should be more realistic and understand that the world’s climate debate is coming to an end. The alarmist dialogue about man—made climate change should be replaced by a more realistic attempt at cooperation among national parliaments to reduce the levels of pollutants in Europe. Member States should not be struggling to comply with unrealistic EU energy standards. National parliaments should be free to exploit their energy resources, bearing in mind the fundamental need to protect their citizens’ health and the environment.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: Mr President, there are also sometimes sensible issues that are put on the political agenda by the establishment parties: clean energy or plastic waste in nature or in the sea, which we can hardly be against. I do not think that the EU should interfere, but they are sensible subjects in themselves.  The question is: why now? Why all of a sudden this excitement? Because when we talk about plastic in the sea, that's been a problem for 10-20 years. In my time in the national parliament, action groups and environmental groups came along to tell them. And they must have been through here, too. There are a lot of Members here who are still there, but so are the parties, who knew about the problems, they knew the seriousness and did nothing then. And now all of a sudden it is!  And that is because old political parties only move when the political agenda is dominated by an unwelcome subject. And that is in this case migration and Islam, the subject of my political movement. This is very popular with the people of Europe, which is why the old political parties have to look for a competitive subject. And they've found it now. But that's not intrinsically motivated! For if that had been the case, the parties that were already in power here in a large majority would have done something about it at that time. And they don't! You can blame them, because that only increases the problem. And you can agree with my political line on migration and Islam or you can disagree, but at least it's intrinsically motivated and consistent, for fifteen years.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, the issue of environmental protection is one of the few issues, in my opinion, on which the European Union's contribution has proved decisive. On the issue of energy security and, more generally, energy saving, I must acknowledge that, in principle, the Union is moving in a positive direction. However, I do not think that the Union's proposals to date answer perhaps the most important question: where will all this energy, which is needed, be found if we abandon both fossil fuels and nuclear energy? Renewable energy sources - despite their positive contribution - are by no means sufficient, at least with today's technologies. Biofuels may also create more problems than they expect to solve.  The second point concerns energy poverty. In most Member States there are some forecasts for strengthening weak economic strata. However, in Greece, for example, these provisions are limited to households with a total family income of less than EUR 11 000-12 000. In practice, it is impossible for a family with an income of EUR 15 000 per year to be able to implement the actions provided for in the reports and renovate their residence in order to achieve energy savings.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As head of the ITRE Committee, I wanted to congratulate all the rapporteurs first of all for achieving this result. It's a really big deal. The objectives are ambitious, I would suggest not to multiply them now, but to focus primarily on completing the task. Because we have a mechanism for managing the Energy Union, because if we want to be credible under the Paris Agreement, we have to meet the objectives that we have decided on. It is also about saving our planet from another threat, in parallel, namely from smog. Four hundred thousand people die prematurely in the European Union, and that is why some of the provisions, I wanted to say, some provisions in the RES Directive are very beneficial from this point of view, for example for the district heating system or for prosumers, which is extremely important in the countryside. On one more point, Mr Blanko López mentioned the need for citizens to support our proposals, I agree. They may also have big ambitions to protect the climate, very well, but in some regions there are as many as forty-one. Such a region is Upper Silesia, which you will come to in a month at COP24. This is where a just energy transition is needed, and it was in the ITRE Committee that we voted on the programme for almost five billion euros. That was the proposal, and mine, that such a programme should be within the budget. We must vote on it on Wednesday, which is very important for our citizens.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: " We arrived here after a great teamwork. I greet all the rapporteurs, also the Commission and the Council. But now the key issue is to call on this team the national powers, the regional powers, the citizens. This is a great strategic opportunity, for the economy, for the environment, for quality of life. We have to work it out. As shadow co-rapporteur for Energy Union Governance, I would like to leave a very special word to my colleague Theresa Griffin, who accompanied me in a stimulating work to strengthen the inclusive, sustainable and innovative dimension of the new European energy policy. I would like to point out some of the results that are in this regulation. Sectoral targets are incorporated. They may not have been the most ambitious, but it is important to meet them: 32.5% in energy efficiency, 32% in renewable energy by 2030. The implementation of the 10-year plans, the comparability of these plans, covering the five dimensions of the Energy Union is very important. We are already taking steps towards the decarbonisation of transport, that is where we must continue, and we must strive for participatory governance, establishing a multilateral dialogue and demanding a very strong mobilisation of civil society. I would also stress the introduction of long-term strategies with the climate strategy so that we can align progress with the Paris Agreement. And also the fair transition. It is very important that citizens, regions, feel that there is a sense of justice in the energy transition, of gain for all in a fair way, strengthening regional cooperation between the Member States and between them and the Union. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that tomorrow we will approve this package with a clear majority, but that is not the point of arrival, that is the starting point. Now we need everyone to do their part, urgently and with commitment, with the same enthusiasm with which we have worked on this package in the European Parliament.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. At the heart of the Clean Power Package is the Energy Union, one of the pillars of which is decarbonisation. I would remind you that the Paris Agreement was reached because decarbonisation had just disappeared from its final shape. I absolutely disagree with decarbonisation. Betting on decarbonisation risks permanently losing the competitiveness of industry and enormous social costs, especially for economies with a high share of coal in the energy mix, such as Poland. Decarbonisation unfortunately takes the mountain over energy solidarity and a just transition. It will hit mining regions such as Silesia hard. The Energy Efficiency Directive, on the other hand, introduces an absurd requirement for an annual reduction of final energy by 0.8%, thus confusing energy efficiency with energy saving. This will threaten economic growth and increase energy poverty. I have more recognition for the Renewable Energy Regulation. The rules on biomass, biofuels and the inclusion of RES in network heating have been designed in a balanced way and I consider them to be a good example of a compromise between what is desirable and what is possible. My concern, on the other hand, is the high overall objective. Germany's example proves that a massive transformation towards RES leads to high costs.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, the Clean Energy Package is really one of the most important and significant pieces of legislation of our mandate and I’m very glad that I have been able to participate in the deliberations. It is absolutely necessary to modernise and shape the energy market, that is for sure, especially if we want to succeed in global competition, but at the same time, we need to focus on the other side of the coin: reducing consumption. It has dropped but, at the same time, we have new technologies, electro-mobility, other sources, renewables, and we obviously will have to focus on further reducing consumption. For me, the question is energy efficiency, an energy efficiency policy first, definitely. I would appreciate it if we could focus on that and I invite the Member States to implement, as soon as possible, as thoroughly as possible, the Clean Energy Package, with an emphasis not just on the opportunities in terms of technology, renewables, etc. but also on lowering consumption.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, in the wake of the alarming UN climate reports, we are meeting this week in Strasbourg to vote on the outcomes of important energy files which will of course affect our climate policies. But on the energy efficiency directive, here we had the opportunity to make some real change. But, as expected, the agreement has been battered and bruised through negotiations with the Council, all the important provisions have been watered down, weakening ambition and reducing obligations on tackling energy poverty to nothing but a footnote. On the Renewable Energy Directive we have an acceptable EU target and even good provisions on making biofuel sustainable. An end to palm oil is in sight but we cannot have any backsliding on this. However, that said, is it wrong of me to expect a directive on renewable energy to be about climate action, rather than paving the way for a liberalised energy market? Climate goals – not an energy market – should be at the heart of these directives.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, Oxfam Germany last week produced a report that claims that European Union biofuels are causing widespread global deforestation, and NGO Fern reported that people’s lives were being threatened by the European Union’s set of clean energy policies. Greenpeace have claimed that the European Union is even choosing to ignore its own advice on biofuels, and another expert academic opinion indicated recently the damage to birdlife from windfarms directly affecting negatively the wildlife food chain. The European Union is, and always has been, a monstrous threat to the environment. In short, the European Union’s strive for clean energy, justified by its obsession with climate change targets, has been – and will continue to be – nothing short of an ecological disaster. And that’s not an epitaph I would want the European Union to have.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Madam President! Thank you to the Commission, rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for a really solid result. You have helped to lay the seeds for a more sustainable European energy system with the new rules. And there is a great deal at stake: the climate of the future, our international climate agreements, and then, in fact, with these rules, we have a huge European growth potential. Our imports are increasing, and so this makes us vulnerable in the European Union in the long run. After all, we cannot continue to become more and more dependent on Putin gas and oil from the Middle East. And so we are also talking about the fact that it is the energy bills of citizens and the competitiveness of businesses and export opportunities that are at stake. If we do not use our energy wiser and better, our companies will pay the price through higher carbon quota prices. It therefore requires ambitious, long-term priorities to put Europe on the right track. All energy is valuable and must be used optimally, therefore the concept of energy efficiency first must be put into practice. The new enforcement rules must ensure that EU countries deliver. European energy policy is only as strong as eu countries make it. It is therefore a question of a good and timely implementation. The updated renewable energy framework provides a clear path for Europe's green transition and global leadership, and even more European innovation and innovation in the bio industry and transport industries, among others.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which With this legislative package, we are taking a major step forward in the energy transition in the European Union. We are creating planning certainty for the Member States, but above all for businesses in the European Union. I believe that we are driving billions of dollars of investment, which will also bring innovation. If you have been in China and you see how the ones in photovoltaics, electric batteries and other green technologies are going with full steam, you have to know that we should be on the lookout. This energy package also helps research and development for efficient and better solutions in Europe. I also see that we must not replace coal-fired power stations with biomass power stations. Bioenergy must not be wasted. Wood and forest residues should be used for the gaps in photovoltaics and wind supply, but not as large-scale power plants, as we unfortunately have with the pellet power plants.
