I also see that in this great transformation, we all have to take it with us. The coal regions have been mentioned. But with the long-term strategy, Commissioner, we also have other social needs – in cities, in regions as well as among citizens. I believe that the climate strategy must also correlate with a social strategy of the European Union.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to express my sincere thanks to Mr Leinen, because we have seen that the import of fossil fuels ultimately entails very high costs. Will the costs for our consumers also fall here? And will there be an increase in purchasing power for our consumers if we focus more on renewable energy and energy efficiency?

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, sir, you are addressing an important issue. Saving energy also means saving costs. This is ultimately reflected in the citizens' pockets, which is the advantage. And with renewable energy, one day we will have paid for the system, and then the energy is free. The sun does not send an invoice. That is the difference with fossil fuels, where we transfer billions to the sheikhs in the Middle East and Putin to Russia every year. The sun and the wind don't send bills. That is why this is beneficial for the economy as well as for every single citizen. You are right.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, a recent report by the International Panel on Climate Change reminded us that swift and ambitious measures are needed to halt global warming. The Clean Energy Package includes reforms to improve energy efficiency, promote the use of renewable energies and organise the governance of the Energy Union. By these means, the Union will seek to achieve its commitments under the Paris Agreement to combat climate change. Improving energy efficiency will also reduce dependence on energy imports from outside the EU and reduce energy costs for households and businesses. At the same time, energy poverty is being relieved, i.e. a situation in which, for example, a retired or unemployed citizen can no longer afford to live in an old home because of its high housing costs. In the coming decades, energy poverty could become an even wider problem in the north, as in Finland, if the price of energy rises faster than people's real earnings. I hope that all good efforts in the energy package will be successful. The EU must play its part in the fight against climate change. At the same time, however, care must be taken to ensure that citizens are guaranteed access to affordable housing and living.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: – Mr President, I am delighted and relieved that, after tomorrow's votes, this House will send a encouraging and real message to all Europeans who are developing the most advanced solutions in the world to reduce emissions. The main focus must be on exiting fossil fuels, and this urgently requires various measures in a wide range of sectors. For example, the transition to low-emission transport is in dire need of emission reductions brought about by sustainable biofuels. Biofuels can be quickly applied to the entire fleet of cars and also to air transport, which unfortunately is growing all the time. I have a question for all those who are opposed to bioenergy in this House. Do you really want to achieve the ambitious emission reductions to which we are committed at EU level? I want, and that is why we need to have decisions like this from the EU that people can prepare for in anticipation.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that the PPE-DE has clearly shown in these negotiations that we are not only in the energy sector for setting incentives – best practice, scoreboard, mapping – for the consumer. I believe that we should legislate for citizens and not prevent, ban, punish, set unrealistic targets against the will of consumers. I believe that the consumer should be at the heart of our decisions. That is why it is also important that we fix technology neutrality in the objectives as much as possible. We know that we spend roughly twice the EU budget on the import of fossil fuels. That is why it is important that the priorities are set correctly – namely, in transport, that we also think about biological and synthetic fuels. Can we invest more in research here? Hybrid technology and, above all, the use of modern technologies for continuous driving in cities, so that we can finally get the red light away in cities, so that millions of cars do not constantly brake and throttle, and therefore particulate matter is at truly frightening heights. Continuous driving and intelligent parking will be an intelligent approach here. Therefore: promotion of machine learning, artificial intelligence, blockchain. Finally, we need to renovate more than 130 million buildings in Europe. There is real potential for manpower and economic growth.

name: Martina WERNER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very We have set ourselves the goal of creating the Energy Union during this parliamentary term. To this end, the Commission, Parliament and the Council have worked very closely together: eight laws have been put in place. This week we are voting on an important part of the energy package. With this vote, four of the eight laws in the package would then be adopted. I would like to congratulate my fellow Members, José Blanco Lopez, Miroslav Poche, Theresa Griffin, and Carlos Zorrinho, for their successes. However, let me also say why this vote is so important: we can only achieve the European energy transition together. For this, we need two things above all: clear targets and jointly agreed plans. And we are voting for both this week. Member States can now coordinate their energy and climate policies much more efficiently. When we have also voted on the electricity market design package, we can all pat ourselves on the back – symbolically. In this parliamentary term, we have really made groundbreaking work for the European energy transition. Finally, Let me also express my particular pleasure at the fact that, for the first time, the governance regulation addresses the problem of energy poverty in an EU act. I believe that this is a very important signal that the European energy transition is not being carried out on the backs of households that are already suffering from the high cost of electricity. It is a signal that we are not leaving anyone behind in Europe.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Just now, my colleague, Mrs Wiśniewska, spoke very competently, as usual, about the support for the district heating system and the important amendments that were adopted on her initiative. These are important amendments for my country, and I think for many interested parties in Europe.   I would suggest that we should perhaps speak less at the declaration level, maybe fewer slogans, fewer slogans, and more specifics. Less elation, and more of what is important, precisely for the households that my speaker has just spoken about. It seems to me that we should look at this through the prism of man, through the prism of many families, including those who do not necessarily live in an economically privileged situation, for whom the changes we are making can have consequences, the question what? Finally, I would like to point out to you that these various proposals are not equally beneficial for all countries, and it is also worth remembering.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We had already set ourselves energy targets by 2020: 20% less energy consumption, more efficiency and more renewables. We are already on the road very well, and it is absolutely right that we should now set ourselves further and new targets by 2030 and beyond. I would like to focus on renewable energies in particular, because there is a great deal to be done. We discussed in the last plenary that, for example, renewable energy infrastructure is on the right track, but in fact it is still far too unambitious. Bioenergy has been mentioned. It is not a question of burning any forests, but also of using waste materials. We really must also be able to use all the energy that is available regionally. Blue energy has not yet been mentioned. In the future, the sea will also offer many things that can be economical, such as wave energy, tidal energy, even energy derived from salt and fresh water. Technology neutral, I think, should be. We need to see which region can contribute what. And then we need an infrastructure to really bring the renewable energy that we produce to consumers and to producers. There is still a lot of work to be done. But I hope that we can do it all together beautifully.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Commissioner Miguel Arias Caete, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Let us imagine that we have a world in which 100% of energy comes from renewable sources and we use this energy so efficiently that there are no problems with nature conservation – e.B. with wind power or biomass – and also no problems with the local residents, because we are restricting it to the areas where it is possible and where we can do the whole thing very much. , use very efficiently. Nobody would think that we were digging big holes, that we were relocating entire villages and then extracting lignite. No one would think that every day we send around EUR 1 billion to Mr Putin and the oil sheikhs to import oil and gas. That is why the objective should be clear to all of us.  But the road is difficult: we need time, we need investment, and we need to take people along the way. That is why I think it is right that we should set ourselves ambitious targets. We have significantly increased the European Commission's proposals. I am also particularly pleased that we are still half a percent more in efficiency than in the case of renewable energies. If we do this together at European level, it will be cheaper and easier. That is why we need European cooperation in this area. I am very pleased that tomorrow we can adopt the three reports in the European Parliament by a large majority.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are more than twenty years away from the first major season of liberalisation of the European gas and electricity markets. However, the European energy market is still unable to provide fair access, high and uniform consumer protection standards, adequate levels of cooperation and interconnection. Energy does not circulate freely everywhere and always, and national prudences on the climate roadmap persist, even if they are different from state to state. I therefore welcome the terms of the Council's agreement on these three dossiers – efficiency, renewables and governance – so that they detail in a persuasive manner and with adequately ambitious European and national targets an important part of the new market structure that the Union urgently needs.  I hope that this agreement augurs well for the current market design negotiations, on the Agency for cooperation between European regulators and on preparing for risk management.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Dear Chairman, I am pleased to adopt this clean energy package after successful negotiations. Together with the Clean Mobility Package, it forms a whole, and together with the basic, umbrella regulations and regulations concerning CO2 emissions, constitutes one complicated and interconnected network of laws, regulations or directives.  The question is that it opens up - have we guessed the right measure, are these laws achievable, are they ambitious enough, or are they perhaps too ambitious? It is also a question of whether the objectives and measures contained in these many directives and regulations are interconnected and will they work together properly? That is why it is important to develop mechanisms to monitor the achievement of these laws so that we can have the right conditions for their review, which is provided for in all of them.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I would like to refer in particular to the directive on the promotion of renewable energy sources. What is important in this directive is support not only for energy producers, for whom it is the main source of activity, but above all for prosumers, i.e. consumers, individuals, companies – especially in rural areas – who have invested or will be able to invest in renewable energy for their own needs, but will also be able to store and resell it. This is important because prosumers will not be able to be ignored by Member States' legislation, as they have often been.  Secondly, I would like to emphasise the role that has been given to local energy communities in this regulation. They can change the shape of the energy market in places which, despite being connected to the grid, do not have a permanent supply of energy. They may also use sources that are related to the circular economy.  Biofuels: we have decided to reduce the amount of biofuels on the market that can pose a high risk to ILUCs, but I also want to stress that biofuels produced from native crops do not compete with food production, and at the same time high-protein feed can be produced in this production, and yet we import this protein – from soybean, for example – from those areas where this ILUC effect also causes soybean. Next-generation biofuels, organic waste from agriculture and forestry are also the future in this sector.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments.  I have the impression that when you talk about efficiency, you do not understand this concept. Technical concepts are difficult to understand. However, when making legislative decisions, we need to know what they are about. We cannot claim that the 32.5% target enshrined in the Efficiency Directive means a 32.5% increase in efficiency. This is a saving of final energy, miscalculated into primary energy. An incorrect understanding of this concept, although the definition given is correct, leads to the omission of important links in the energy flow chain with the greatest potential for efficiency improvement. The Commission, by adopting one unrealistic PEF indicator, does not understand its role in shaping efficiency trends. Commissioner, the Efficiency Directive is, in my opinion, a legislative bub, because it concerns restrictions on energy use, not real efficiency.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, the energy issue we are discussing today is particularly important because it touches all the Member States, but also all European citizens, the economy and society. My country, Cyprus, is paying a hard price because of climate change. There is prolonged unemployment and water scarcity, which is really unbearable, the agricultural costs, but also the costs for every household and for every Cypriot citizen. I imagine, however, that the same applies to every European citizen.  The European Union must react. React by taking action for those who suffer the consequences of climate change. Because the European Union can react and make innovative and original investments, particularly on our islands, which are suffering from this important problem. To set up desalination plants or, at the same time, large photovoltaic parks to reduce electricity costs, i.e. energy costs, which are particularly important for the survival of these countries and in particular for the primary production sector. However, it is also important for the secondary sector, since photovoltaics will be able to reduce energy there as well. Therefore, the European Union can invest in every house, in every business and in every agricultural production, an autonomous energy system, which will also contribute to renewable energy sources.  At the same time, we support the Energy Union. We support and support it because we believe that Cyprus and its energy reserves will be within the Energy Union and the European Union must be able to support, support and safeguard Cyprus' energy reserves. These stocks are important because, since Cyprus is a Member State of the European Union, they are part of the European energy reserves.

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: – I would like to ask a few questions. First, will this energy package work once there are optional targets in general at European Union level? And secondly, will it work when we do not have specific targets for each Member State? That was the case with the first pack and it worked with the famous goals 20-20-20. The second question I would like to raise is whether we should finally put electricity grids first, because when we set ambitious renewable energy and energy efficiency targets, they will be impossible to implement if we do not have further development of the energy supply system, namely energy transmission networks. And the last question, perhaps to Mr. Commissioner, tell me, how is it possible that in a city like Shenzhen in China, which has 15,000 electric buses, there could be more electric buses than all over Europe?

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, allow me to first of all begin my contribution this evening by paying tribute to the excellent Parliament negotiating team that worked together over the past two years to deliver what is an extremely positive result for this institution. Thanks to Mr Blanco López, Mr Federley, Mr Henkel, Mr Tamburrano, Ms López Bermejo and, of course, Mr Claude Turmes, who has since moved on to pastures new – we wish him the best in the Luxembourg Government. In addition, I think there is great praise due to the Bulgarian Presidency and particularly Minister Stankov for excellent cooperation over the course of the negotiations. This is a negotiation that has yielded some extremely important results for the renewable energy sector by providing the much needed—ambition and certainly to drive investments into the environment of renewable energy across Europe. Indeed, this is also a great result for consumers, on whom there is a big focus in the text. I strongly welcome the agreement that we ultimately reached here in Strasbourg, at 4 am on the morning of 14 June – an agreement that will ensure that 32% of energy used in the European Union by 2030 comes from renewable energy sources, such as wind, solar, biomass, ocean or geothermal, etc.  This is significant, and the fact that we expect the text to be strongly supported in the vote tomorrow is testament to this House’s recognition of the importance of the switch to renewable energy and the enormous potential it brings for us all. This is not only about contributing to the EU’s 40% emissions reductions by 2030, in accordance with our Paris Agreement pledge. Nor is it only about increasing the efficiency of energy markets and improving air quality. Renewable energy is a rapidly growing sector, and is now contributing a significant amount of jobs globally. Global employment and renewable energy sectors reached 10.3 million jobs in 2017. This is up 5.3% on the previous year, 2016, and it continues to grow rapidly. Our ambitious text will help to create EU leadership in these sectors and prevent jobs being lost to the rapidly expanding renewables industry in other parts of the world.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Energy transition is a necessity, we all know this, and the combination of these three dossiers shows how serious differences are not only within this Chamber within the political groups, but within individual countries. What makes us different first and foremost? Almost everything: pace, scope, responsibility, costs, level of management, sources of regulation, as I would point out, because on the one hand it points, for example, to smog, on the other hand to economics, from another to the sources of poverty. I would like to draw attention to this at the moment, because tools and their adequacy will be used to address certain issues in individual countries in the interests of reconciling these various interests.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the objective of an energy Union based on an ambitious climate policy is to provide European consumers with safe, sustainable, competitive and affordable energy. The new Regulation on the governance of the Energy Union will enable Europe to become a world leader in renewable energy, putting energy efficiency first and offering fair treatment to consumers.  The compromise reached with the Council has set important objectives, even if they are well below Parliament's expectations. The targets of 32 % renewable energy in the European Union's energy mix are 32.5 % energy saving by 2030 will have to be achieved through coordinated action at European, macro-regional, regional, national and local level.  The ultimate objective of a fully functional and resilient Energy Union is to transform the European Union into a leading region for innovation, investment, growth and a credible example of the pursuit of high ambitions in climate change mitigation policy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Mr Cañete, I will come back to an issue I have raised several times. It concerns the emission allowances of gaseous pollutants paid by the Public Electricity Company in Greece, PPC. It currently pays EUR 400 million per year. Next year, because the rights have been expensive, it will pay EUR 600 million per year. Beware, however: Greece is close to Albania, which is not bound by any rules, as well as Skopje, Turkey and Bulgaria, but which is excluded and does not pay gas emission allowances. The same is true of Polish PPC. And I ask you: should this exception not be provided for Greek electricity generation, i.e. the exception to Article 10 of Directive 2003/87/EC? Because the criterion was GDP. GDP in Greece in 2013 was 62%. In 2014, however, it was 59.7% of average Community GDP. We've been destroyed by the memoranda. We must join this exception in order to have cheap energy and to develop production.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Madam President. The adoption of the Energy Union is one of the key objectives of this mandate of the Commission and Parliament. I am therefore very pleased to welcome the package of three clean energy regulations. This is the use of renewable sourcing and, of course, energy efficiency and, of course, the governance of the Energy Union. Reducing energy consumption is certainly the first step, and it is also very important to accelerate the use of renewable resources, to also create new green jobs through this measure, to reduce energy poverty, and to keep Europe and become a leading force in the fight against climate change. We may only generate 10 percent of the world's greenhouse gases, but Europe has been here for decades, showing the way the whole world must evolve. I therefore very much support and congratulate both the rapporteurs and the Commissioner for accepting this package.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, much of the globe is not blessed with the prosperity enjoyed by Western civilization. The reasons for this are different, but this is an indisputable fact.   In order for the rest of the world to develop seamlessly, which requires energy without endangering the planet we live on, energy efficiency and the share of renewables need to be increased. Energy has always been an extremely important weapon in geopolitical calculations, so Europe needs energy independence. Reduced consumption and sustainable clean energy production play an important role here.   I support ambitious plans in this direction, but I stress that we must be careful so that political ambitions do not endanger industry and cause economic stagnation and job losses. So we would weaken our global position and annul all the good we have achieved on the energy front.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, in my introductory statement I underlined how important these dossiers are for the clean energy transition in addressing the climate change challenge, considering the important contribution of energy efficiency and renewable energy to the greenhouse gas emission reductions, and how much progress we are making for setting the framework for our ambition until 2030. This will be good for the planet, the economy and consumers. But let me end this debate with a clear message that we are not finished yet. We want to look beyond 2030, following on from the call from this House in the run-up to last year’s COP23. After a similar call from European Union leaders this March, the Commission is preparing a European Union long-term strategy on greenhouse gas emission reduction, which is due to be adopted by the College of Commissioners at the end of this month. In our strategy we will factor in the latest findings from science and in particular the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s Special Report on global warming of 1.5°C. We will look at what should be required to achieve the Paris goals and we will explore different pathways as required by Article 15 of the Governance Regulation, including the scenarios to achieve net zero emissions. I signal to you my intention to come to Parliament to present this document the day that it is adopted, if so agreed by this House. Let me close by thanking you again for our excellent cooperation and for being such a reliable partner in the course of the negotiations of this dossier. I trust that in your vote tomorrow and in the remaining negotiations that lie ahead, you will maintain your ambitious approach and thereby remain such an important player in defining our future energy policy fit for the 21st century and instrumental for achieving our climate commitments under the Paris Agreement.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, first of all, I would like to correct an omission and sincerely thank the Commission, the Council and all the co-ministers for their excellent cooperation. Thanks to them. I especially thank Claude Turmes who has contributed a great deal to this success. This report is a real team effort and, really, I want to thank all the partners. Secondly, with regard to COP24, it would be nice to consider a scenario with a reference of 1.5oC, because the Commission has an important role to play in defending the Union's proposals at this conference. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, if there is one project in this Parliament, the European dimension of which seems to me to be indisputable, it is this one. I think that the project we have built together shows the anti-Europeans what Europe is capable of. This project is forward-looking, it aims to protect the planet and humanity, it proposes energy independence - as my colleague mentioned in the talk of geostrategy - and, at the same time, it can respond to energy insecurity. It is therefore a promising European project that shows what Europe is capable of. When I think of the next European elections, I think that this is a good example and that, if there were many other European projects like this, no one would question the usefulness of Europe. Yes, we need it.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to thank you very much for this debate and conclude by highlighting a particularly important element of this regulation. Carbon budgets are one of the most important instruments we have to ensure a scientifically robust climate policy. It is an easy-to-understand and effective instrument that ensures that we achieve our climate goals. It is therefore great that this tool is now being introduced into this legislation for the first time in an EU context. It is about time climate policy was treated with the same seriousness as fiscal policy. A European carbon budget opens up the possibility of that. Then we can see, black and white, how much carbon we have left to spend and reconcile our climate action against that amount. Just as Europe's finance ministers are today being held accountable for the budgets of their countries, I hope that the climate ministers of the Member States will face the same treatment. It should not be possible to overdraft one country's carbon account without consequences. More work remains to be done before we are there, but the vote tomorrow is an incredibly important first step. Building on this work on the road to future European cohesion, ambitious climate law, with a proper emission budget for the Union, we can bring about climate policy. We must take seriously the concerns of citizens about the extreme weather events that we are now seeing across Europe. We must ensure that our voters get the climate policy they expect.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is at stake transcends a directive. What is at stake is the future of the planet. The agreements we have reached in renewables, efficiency and governance are important not only because we have managed to raise the ambition of this standard. They are important because they put Europe on the path of compliance with the Paris Agreements and the Sustainable Development Goals. Because they align Europe's promises with facts that make them possible. Because they reaffirm Europe's global leadership by signaling where the world should walk. That's what I need to do. It is urgent to raise the objectives at the Climate Summit in order to mitigate the consequences of global warming. It is urgent because, as the IPCC has just emphasized in its latest report, climate change is a reality of very serious consequences for ecosystems, human health and the economy. And what's coming is worse if we don't act. It is urgent because it is also crucial for our development and for our future competitiveness. There's no alternative. It's here and it's now, there won't be another chance. Let us therefore support these measures and continue, as many colleagues have shown, let us continue to work tirelessly to move forward and, if possible, to move faster in that struggle for all to save the planet. This is a step forward, but we have a long way to go.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
