name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – The Clean Energy Package aims to modernise the EU's electricity system and respond to the most pressing economic and energy challenges. One of these, if not the most serious, is global warming. The latest IPCC study paints a much gloomier picture of the climate situation than previously thought, which is why it is particularly important that we deal with this problem properly. It is essential to permanently and significantly reduce CO2 emissions from Member States, so it is important to support carbon-neutral technologies in energy production. In Hungary, CO2 emissions per unit of electricity production are currently among the lowest, but the Hungarian Government intends to further reduce this in its energy strategy. The two pillars of future Hungarian energy production are solar and nuclear energy, which would play their part in the country's energy supply in almost half to half. It is common in these technologies that they do not e-pollute and are therefore not harmful to the climate or air quality. I believe that with such forward-looking strategies, we can respond appropriately to the challenges of our time.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Europeans are increasingly and more severely affected by the negative consequences of exceeded air standards, cities are fighting smog, and the number of pollution-related illnesses is increasing. There is therefore no doubt that it is necessary to increase the share of clean energy in the European energy mix. Certainly, an ambitious policy in this area is needed, but we must ensure that, in carrying out such a policy, account is also taken of the real capabilities of the Member States and the real costs. I am therefore opposed to the introduction of binding commitments for individual Member States on the share of renewable energy in their energy mix. It is necessary to apply a flexible approach which takes account of the specificities of each Member State.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – The third legislative package regulated energy efficiency and renewable development over a decade in which few European leaders denied climate change were few. It is no longer disputed that we are the cause of climate change, but if the RECOMMENDATIONS of the IPCC are underestimated, which, although they warn of the serious consequences of emissions, the reductions necessary to limit the overall temperature to +1.5o are not expected to be achieved. 85% of the world's primary energy is burning oil, coal and gas, which the IMF says receives more than 4.7 trillion euros per year in subsidies. While bodies such as the OECD call on world leaders to limit these subsidies and decarbonise the economy, the agreements reached in the new Directives are not ambitious enough. While the Energy Governance Regulation will ensure compliance with renewables and efficiency objectives, avoiding past mistakes, without complicing planning, or adjustment mechanisms, more ambition and conviction on the part of our leaders will be necessary if we are to be a global leader in the fight against the greatest threat facing humanity.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – The European Union must defend its leading role in the fight against climate change. The European Union has shown that sustainable growth is possible. While we have reduced our emissions by 23%, GDP has increased by 53%. We will also achieve the 2020 targets ahead of schedule. The European Union must continue to pursue ambitious but realistic targets to reduce emissions. The aim is to increase the EU's energy efficiency by 32.5% and increase the share of renewable energy to 32% by 2030. These are important steps towards reducing emissions and ways of responding to the commitments of the Paris Agreement on climate change.  Climate change must be combated now that global warming can still be affected. The European Parliament must stick to its line that the European Union should tighten its own emissions reduction target to 55% in 2030. The European Union is a world pioneer in the fight against climate change. The only sector where emissions have increased in the EU is transport. For this reason, for the first time, co2 emission limits are also being set for lorries in addition to new passenger cars. However, the European Union cannot prevent climate change alone. Since emissions within the European Union account for less than 10% of global emissions, the Union must actively work to get big emitters to commit to common goals.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the report by Ruža Tomašić, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the multiannual plan for small pelagic species in the Adriatic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks (COM(201) 7)0097 – C8-0095/2017 –2017/0043(COD)) (A8-0337/2018).

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: The Rapporteur. – Dear Chairman, the prosperity of man is closely linked to his attitude towards nature. Despite technological advances that have drastically improved the quality of life for most of the planet, without nature and its resources, man cannot achieve the fullness of his existence. Our place at the top of the food chain also carries certain responsibilities. One of them is rational management of natural resources, and we have often been underdiaded as both Europeans and people. Protecting fish stock is high on the list of priorities for both parties in this debate and that is what makes me particularly happy. Our primary motive is the same and we are looking towards the same goal, but the path we want to get there is somewhat different. No one disputes the need for a multiannual bluefish management plan in the Adriatic, but we must resist some simple solutions that would ruin the fishing industry. The Commission considers that pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea can best be protected by quotas, which fishermen and professional associations from countries exiting the Adriatic, their governments, the European Social and Economic Council, medac, the majority in the European Parliament's Fisheries Committee and myself as rapporteur agree with.  This view of the Commission is to ignore the good results of existing practices recommended by the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean and the harmful play on the fates of hundreds of thousands of people. The Commission claims that it consulted stakeholders in drafting the proposal, but it is unclear which stakeholders they are, as, as I have already said, both the policy and the profession in the countries concerned by this plan are strongly against the Commission's proposal. The consultation process was clearly flawed or its conclusions were eventually ignored. They also seem to have realised in the Commission that their ideas do not have too many allies – neither among fishermen, nor among scientists, nor among member states going out to the Adriatic Sea or in this home – so they put an escapement strategy on the back door.  I am absolutely in line with considering all alternatives to the Commission's initial harmful proposal to introduce drastic quotas that would destroy the fishing sector in the Adriatic and later the entire Mediterranean, and strengthen the economy of third states at the expense of the Union's members. The conclusion of the profession is that the effects of the escapement strategy cannot yet be accurately predicted, and that is why we should leave the discussion about it for the future, when scientific research will be able to give us more concrete information.  The multiannual plan for the management of small blue fish in the Adriatic is not adopted in five or ten years, but now. It must be based on practices that have proven to work, not on someone's desires or political ambitions. Currently, for the entire Adriatic area, a Management Plan of the General Commission for Mediterranean Fisheries is in force, regulating fishing effort and capacity through spatial-time regulation and limiting the number of fishing days per vessel. In Croatia, Italy and Slovenia, countries that consistently follow the GFCM recommendations, they are already delivering tangible results and there is no reason why the continuity of fish stock protection should be broken by new measures of a completely different nature. The annual 4% reduction in catches for each Member State, from 2014 as a reference year, which I propose in this report is a reasonable measure in line with the GFCM recommendations and represents a continuation of proven effective efforts.  Unfortunately, the Commission has once again shown that it is unaware of the regional differences between north and south of Europe. Quotas from the north can't work in the south. The introduction of quotas in the Adriatic and then in the entire Mediterranean affects not only the fishing fleet, but also the processing industry and tun farms that depend on small blue fish. To survive, the processing industry and tuna farmers will have to import fish from third countries. This means that the European Union is destroying the economy of its own members through legislation and strengthening the economic and political position of others.  This is not the first time that the Commission has hit the interests of Member States and Union citizens who want to live off their work through poor policy, but Parliament should not agree to such a game.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Tomašić, the shadow rapporteurs and their teams, as well as the Committee on Fisheries, for the long work on this important proposal for the Mediterranean. This is a proposal for a first EU multiannual plan in the Mediterranean. Having a meaningful plan in place is crucial, given the overall dramatic state of the stocks in the area, with around 85% of the assessed stocks being over—exploited. In the Adriatic, the picture emerging from the most recent scientific assessments on small pelagics is crystal clear and extremely worrying. The fishing mortality is too high for both sardine and anchovy, and the spawning biomass is at very low levels. While there are slight signs of improvement for sardine, anchovy has a high probability of collapse within one to three years unless drastic action is taken. I want to be very clear: we need to avoid a collapse of anchovy as we had in the past in the Bay of Biscay. We must act now and not allow a new case of collapse in EU waters.  Such a collapse is not only about the fish in the sea, but also about the jobs on land. To be precise, the sector employs 1330 direct jobs in Croatia, around 1000 in Italy, and more in Slovenia. Catches are worth around EUR 85 million per year. This excludes the secondary sector, with 570 processing enterprises with at least 6700 employees on its own and worth EUR 150 million. This is why I have put forward an ambitious and serious proposal, capable of effectively guaranteeing the long—term viability of these jobs and the benefits for EU citizens. I wish to be absolutely clear on this point: without the steps taken in the Commission’s proposals, it is only a matter of one to three years before the stock will fail and, in doing so, we would have most certainly failed the industry and EU citizens. This multiannual plan was designed to allow these stocks to recover. Unfortunately, the majority of amendments voted by the Committee on Fisheries are of serious concern and very problematic for the Commission. They are not in line with the basic principles and objectives of the common fisheries policy (CFP); they deviate massively from the approach agreed in other multiannual plans that are already adopted, like the North Sea and Baltic; and they derogate from key legislation, such as the Mediterranean Regulation, the current European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) and the control regulation. Most importantly, some amendments would remove entirely the obligation to reach FMSY or any target with a clear timeline, would eliminate the need to take safeguard measures if certain biomass levels are not reached, and would minimise remedial actions. Amendment 48 also dilutes the landing obligation, which is a central element of the CFP reform. Moreover, amendments completely ignored the scientific advice according to which anchovy and sardines should be managed separately and removed the possibility of setting fishing opportunities on the basis of FMSY. Finally, the report, as adopted in committee, introduces provisions such as a 2% reduction of the combined catch level of 2014 over the next four years. This is freezing the catch levels at their recent peak, which would neither prevent the collapse of anchovy nor bring the stocks close to FMSY. Such amendments are much less ambitious than what has already been agreed with third countries in the multilateral context of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), meaning the deductions of 5% per year in the next three years. All this sends the wrong message to our partners around the Mediterranean – in particular, after all the efforts deployed into garnering their support for serious actions in favour of sustainable fisheries in both the MEDFISH4EVER declaration and the GFCM. It is also essential to avoid double standards, whereby northern European Member States have to comply with FMSY and clear timelines, while southern Member States have targets not in line with FMSY and no set timelines. Being the first Mediterranean multiannual plan, this would set a bad precedent. Therefore, I have to be very clear that these texts are not acceptable for the Commission. Keeping them would result in a make—believe multiannual plan, which would be nothing more than a set of transitional measures that essentially will allow to maintain current excessive overfishing. This is not enough, and this is not what we all promised European citizens when we adopted the current CFP. Finally, to end on a positive note, there were a number of sensible amendments in the Committee on Fisheries which had been proposed to address some of the criticisms from the sector on the introduction of tax. These concerned notably the introduction of an MSY biomass escapement strategy. In the end, they were not approved by the Committee on Fisheries but have been re—tabled for tomorrow’s plenary vote. If adopted tomorrow, the Commission is ready to examine these amendments in the light of scientific advice. We count on your support to take a responsible decision that will allow us to live up to the basic principles and commitments of our CFP and to the standards of other multiannual action plans. Only if we deliver on our joint commitments can we ensure the recovery of the stocks, and thus the profitability of the fleet and livelihood of the coastal communities which depend on them in the mid— and long—term.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, your presentation is embarrassing. I have no other way of defining it, because you are well aware that you have put forward a proposal which, if you had the courage, would have had to withdraw and then present another strategy, that of escapement, which, quite rightly – there are forwarded e-mails demonstrating this – from the Commission passed as an amendment for one of our colleagues. This is an absolutely undemocratic act and a prevarication of Parliament's prerogatives, for which the Commission should apologise. I am sorry to ask, because we could also accept the escapement strategy if we could amend and improve it and not take it as an amendment by a colleague, rather than an afterthought by the Commission. Having said that, it is clear that the Commission has the political will to kill fisheries in favour of aquaculture, which could also be a strategy, but I do not know whether you also want mad fish after mad cow disease. I would like to be able to catch fish that have grown and lived at sea and that are nutritionally positive and good for my citizens, starting with the children to whom I do not want to give the fish that are bred who knows where and who knows how. Have you ever taken salmon, a few years ago above all, that when you put it in the oven all the white foam came out because suddenly the salmon was so fat, coming from your farms, that it was inedible. I was passionate about salmon and I don't eat any more. What has come out of the Committee on Fisheries is a balanced text, an excellent summary and also in line with the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. You always talk about supranational things, adapt to supranational bodies, do not go against supranational bodies.  Italian fishing has already received an incredible cull, since 2000 it has more than halved. Of course the catch has decreased, but there are ecosurveys that tell us that stocks are much better than your models say. Do you want to believe reality or reality needs your theoretical models to be true. But shame on you!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, according to recent scientific advice, stocks of sardines and anchovies are overfished in the Adriatic Sea. As shadow rapporteur, I supported the multiannual plan for the Adriatic Sea as a tool for the management of marine biological resources, with the aim of rebuilding stocks and restoring the sustainability of the sector. The management measures proposed by the rapporteur, Mrs Tomašić, are insufficient to ensure the survival of small pelagic stocks and the absence of decisive action could lead to the collapse of stocks in a very short time. The figures are clear and agree with those of the Commission's Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries. In recent years there has also been a sharp reduction in the average size of the catch. Only a few vessels that have direct agreements with large companies operating in intensive industrial fishing would benefit from the rapporteur's proposal. The majority of small Italian fishermen, on the other hand, would need a regulation that would guarantee work for everyone, even for years to come.  I have tabled amendments on the Biomass Escapement Strategy, which I believe can be a good compromise to protect sufficient biomass to guarantee the sustainability and re-breeding of stocks, but also flexibility in the event of abundant vintages. The amendments provide for the proposal by the rapporteur, Mrs Tomašić – a 4 % reduction in catches – to be adopted for the next three years, and that from 2023, if stocks are not safe, we will move on to the Biomass Escapement Strategy. This strategy is also shared by the most representative Italian fishing trade associations such as Federpesca and Coldiretti Impresa Pesca. I therefore ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to support the amendments on the Biomass Escapement Strategy to ensure that small pelagics continue to be a source of income for our fishermen in the future.

name: Czesław HOC
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab At the outset, I would like to congratulate and sincerely thank My colleague Mrs Tomašić for a very important report on the multiannual plan for small pelagic species in the Adriatic Sea and for fishing for these stocks. I would like to stress that we have a generational duty to pursue sustainable levels of fishing for these fish and to take a proper approach to the marine ecosystem. It is necessary to fishery at such a level as to achieve MSY, i.e. maximum sustainable fishing, but it must be borne in mind that anchovies and sardines are an important economic element in the incomes of the fisheries sectors of individual countries. The multiannual plan must be based on scientific facts in total symbiosis with public opinion and with good practice of individual countries fishing in this basin, so the exploitation of small pelagic species in the Adriatic Sea must, on the one hand, be based on stable and effective governance foundations and implemented in terms of a generational perspective, but on the other hand respect for science and public opinion.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Madam President, Commissioner, there is no doubt the multiannual plans are not only instruments in line with our common fisheries policy, but also instruments of responsibility, because they are aimed at protecting stocks and creating fish stocks that can be used appropriately by the population. It is a certainty, colleagues, that in the Adriatic Sea sardine and yearstocks are overexploited. That is why I believe that measures and measures must be taken that are useful and reality in practice immediately, because any continuation of this over-exploitation can destroy fish stocks, and I do not think that is what anyone wants. Certainly, the fact that the drastic measures proposed by the Commission affect communities in the area and local and regional economies is a certainty, and in this context we must take steps to find solutions to fill these jobs. We also believe that the measures to be taken must be close to scientific data solutions but also to the solutions adopted by GFCM, and we regret that this report only talks about management measures after the first three years, which does not enable - in my view - to adopt long-term measures. We believe that it is necessary to have a long-term view of this situation and our proposals have not been accepted, which - in my view - raises a big problem still in relation to the management of these stocks. I would like to stress that the measures proposed only for this period are relatively balanced, but we do not consider them sufficient, and we believe that this approach must be balanced and balanced, favouring communities as well as fish stocks.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not be able to do so. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in two minutes I would have had a real hard time listing all the points that concern me about this plan, which passed through the Committee on Fisheries, but fortunately many of them were mentioned by Commissioner Vella. I have been in this European Parliament for four and a half years and I have been hearing in the Committee on Fisheries about the disastrous situation in the Mediterranean, 85 % of overexploited species, a sector in serious difficulty. Yet now that the multiannual plans, which are one of the pcp's own principled instruments, are coming, we can see immediately how much they are being diluted, forgotten, ruined, reduced to something that makes no sense, no value, no effectiveness.  The Adriatic plan included quotas as an initial proposal. In the Mediterranean, quotas cannot be talked about, they are taboo and they are something that cannot even be taken into account. Colleagues who are so concerned about the socio-economic consequences do not think about the socio-economic fallout of a stock that can collapse, and which would therefore leave the people who work and earn on this stock on foot, and do not even think about the fact that where stocks are fished in a sustainable way, the profitability of fishing has increased considerably and therefore with great socio-economic return.  Now we have a plan on our hands that we've never seen in the other multi-year plans we've made. It is not multiannual because it lasts only three years. The concept of maximum sustainable yield has disappeared and, above all, it does not listen to the concerns of science or rather choose which science to listen to. I would remind Mrs Gardini that the Ecosurveys you mentioned are made about demersals, whereas this is a plan for pelagics. These are two data that cannot be put together, it would take a minimum of scientific knowledge to know. Instead, STECF tells us that stocks are in serious crisis and that one of them is in danger of collapsing. So we need a much more effective measure than we have in this plan and I hope that the alternative that you will have on the list tomorrow, that of the Escapement Strategy, can at least pass to give fishermen support themselves with this economic resource.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the Mediterranean is large and the Mediterranean is deep, but the bottom is still in sight. Fish and other species in the Mediterranean are disappearing at a worrying rate, particularly in the Adriatic, where half of all marine mammals and fish have disappeared in the last 50 years alone. Scientists warn that the pressure on the ecosystem is so great that if we do nothing now, the point of no return is imminent. There's no going back if we continue on this footing. Then the plant and animal species in the Adriatic will be doomed. In recent years I have been closely involved in the fisheries plans of the North Sea and the Baltic Sea and these plans have not been very good, but this plan for the Adriatic is absolutely everything. This is a carte blanche for overfishing, a carte blanche to eradicate anchovies and sardines, species that are very important for the Adriatic ecosystem. I therefore believe that the rapporteurs who drew up this fisheries plan should be very ashamed of themselves. They are jesing the survival of ecosystems, and I hope that Parliament will put a stop to this. The Adriatic needs a rescue plan, a plan that stops overfishing now and not in three years, now, as agreed in the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. I also believe that European agricultural and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 70-80 % of Italian sardines and anchovies are produced in the Adriatic and more than 160 vessels and a thousand operators operate. In the last five years, however, the supply chain has lost 50-60 % of its value as a result of competition. That is why we have thought of management interventions that take proper account of the real state of resources and that are not based only on precautionary approaches. In general, before the adoption of a management plan, it would be appropriate to carry out an impact assessment, both on the real availability of fish stocks and on socio-economic aspects, as also established by the basic regulation on the common fisheries policy, which closely affect micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, which are mainly Italian. The introduction of a quota system risks leading the entire sector to collapse after more than twenty years of crisis. The aim of this plan is to achieve and maintain maximum sustainable yield for the stocks concerned, to make the fisheries sector sustainable and to provide an effective management framework. This proposal for a regulation opposes the Commission's attempts to set quotas. Just as we will vote on it tomorrow, it offers stability in this area. Any change from this strategy could disrupt the EU market, open up room to increase imports from third countries and put the fisheries sector in an unfair market position. The proposal voted on in the Committee on Fisheries, on the other hand, is based on management of fishing effort and represents the real need of the sector with biological sustainability, but also economic and social sustainability. Tomorrow we are voting with our consciences.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, this strategic file has been long awaited and I hope that we will avoid any unnecessary delays. The aim of this proposal is to establish a framework for the management of Adriatic pelagic stocks. It should provide a balanced approach to the sustainable exploitation of these stocks, because this will lead to the stability of fishing opportunities, and that in turn will lead to the secure livelihood of fishermen. At the same time, it should guarantee that this management is based on the most up—to—date scientific advice regarding the status of stocks covered, and also interactions between species and other aspects related to the ecosystem and fisheries. There are two points I would like to mention right now. Firstly, the most important thing is the implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy – the reform and the regionalisation as well. The voice of the regions must be heard and put into practice. Secondly, I have always been a big supporter of flexibility of management plans. They should be flexible enough to react to changes in fish populations based on scientific advice, and I hope that the negotiating team will be striving for this during their trilogue negotiations.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome you for your speech. The main and final objective of the Common Fisheries Policy is for the activity to be carried out in the most sustainable way possible, not only from an economic point of view, but also from a social, economic and environmental point of view. All scientific advice shows that the situation of small pelagics in the Adriatic is critical and that additional specific and concrete management measures that allow the recovery of antby and sardine populations need to be urgently implemented. The proposal adopted by the Fisheries Commission is currently due to its temporal limitation, since the proposed management measures are limited to 2022 and change very little the measures that are currently implemented and that the different scientific advice indicates that they are not sufficient. After intensive negotiations and talks between the different stakeholders, a consensus was found that allows, without changing the rapporteur's proposal, to define management measures to be implemented after 2022 and substantially alterthe form of management advocated so far. With the amendments submitted by the Socialists and Democrats, it is intended to ensure that, with scientific information collected annually, catches are defined to keep reproductive biomass close to a constant level. In S&D, we argue that only with these additional measures will it be possible to maintain this fishery and prevent the collapse of small pelagics in the Adriatic. The Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries concludes that small pelagic populations will collapse if only measures such as those proposed by the rapporteur are maintained. Fao's General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean assessments also go in the same direction. Knowing that the effects will be enormous for fishermen, businesses and local communities in the short and medium term, I encourage you tomorrow to vote in favour of Amendments 93 and 97.  Mrs. Tomašić, there may be a sea with fish and without fishermen, there may be a sea with fish and with fishermen. One thing is certain: there can be no sea without fish and with fishermen. Without a constant biomass of available breeders, there will be no recruitment and, as there are no spontaneous generations in nature, without recruitment there will be no fish and without fish there will be no fishermen.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Tomašić, on her report. It is a balanced report, which takes into account the protection of local communities and the major socio-economic problems that may arise.  Mr Vella, I have spoken to the Greek fishermen and asked for their opinion. I have therefore been told that they are satisfied with the arrangements of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GPM) currently in force. These are measures taken in 2016 that provide solutions to the problems, so I can say that fishermen are happy. However, we must be careful, said the Greek fishermen, the purse seines, which over-fish and have disastrous consequences. In this respect, a great deal of protection is required. Moreover, what the Greek fishermen, who have been impoverished by the memoranda, are asking for is investment. It is the possibility to modernise their fishing fleet. To be able to fish beyond the Adriatic and in areas other than the Greek seas, so that they can save their profession. These are the issues that greek fishermen raise, Mr Vella.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I want to support Mrs. Tomašić's report right from the beginning because this report that she set it up works for the benefit of those people who are engaged in fishing in the Adriatic.  I would like to remind you that I was rapporteur for the Adriatic and Ionian macrostrategy of the European Union, where fisheries are also one of the pillars of this macrostrategy.  Blue growth. What kind of blue growth will we have if we start to introduce this kind of policy proposed by the Commission? I want to be absolutely clear: here we have an almost historic agreement between Croatian, Italian and Slovenian fishermen. I don't remember when it happened around any topic. This is what happened now. Please, Gentlemen of the Commission, please, colleagues and colleagues, to take this fact into account and to benefit those who live off fish. Well, I guess they think a little more about their future than I hear here sometimes, from some, mind-care. I understand some thesis, but I do not understand why we should go against those who are living from fishing on the Adriatic right now.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Madam President, once an average size of 15 centimetres, sardines now measure only 11 centimetres in the Mediterranean. Anchovies are also affected by this alarming phenomenon. Worse, these pelagics are now dying much younger, so much so that sardines and anchovies over two years old have disappeared. The small size of fish of course has an impact on their marketing, but it also raises the issue of pollution, which has never been more serious, especially in the Mediterranean, and which also affects plankton, the main diet of these fish. It is of course essential to manage the stocks, but this could be done without the European Union, since it is the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean that has jurisdiction in this area at the international level. The European Union would be more useful if it urgently stopped the release of polluting chemicals in the Mediterranean rather than making major statements on the environment. Talking is good, dealing with causes is better.

name: Werner KUHN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mrs Tomasic, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. This plan is a logical consequence of what we have developed over several years, so to speak, on the basis of the basic regulations for the common fisheries policy: the Baltic Sea Plan, the North Sea Plan, Western Waters. Of course, we also need to look closely at stocks in the Mediterranean. There is no question about that. In the Adriatic, we are talking about a fishing area that is relatively clearly defined – also geographically clearly defined – sardines and anchovies, pelagic species, which are ultimately caught either by silent fishing or by trawling.  The scientific evaluations on biomass are necessary and have been carried out over the years, but they also have a tolerance range of between -20% and +20%. That is why we must also be very careful about quoting, because it will be the first time that we have tackled this, so to speak, within the Mediterranean. It is our common goal: maximum sustainable yield. If this quota is introduced and a drastic reduction is envisaged for fisheries, for the small sector, then of course there must also be socio-economic measures, which we accompany from the EMFF, from the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund: temporary decommissioning, which will then also be remunerated accordingly, catch loss premiums, which are remunerated accordingly. The Member States must also start cofinancing there. In this way, we can only organise a recovery plan that has been in place for several years, so that stocks can then recover. This is also very important for fisheries. Of course, we do not want small-scale and small-scale fishing to go bankrupt, so to speak, but we must support it financially until the biomass is again so clear and so clear that there will be good production of young talent. In this sense, I can only say that our common objective is maximum sustainable yield – maximum sustainable yield – to preserve jobs, but also to maintain the tourist attractiveness of these fishing ports on the Adriatic. In this sense, we must approach this Adriatic plan with reason.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, who comes from the Mediterranean, ladies and gentlemen, the Mediterranean is dying and we are watching it die. Not only do tankers clean their tanks, not only does the intensity of traffic lead to polluting collisions like last month's, but it also drains its wealth due to our inability to regulate fishing activity. Parliament's report on the multi-year plan for small pelagic people in the Adriatic Sea does not take into measure of these issues. Of course, the Commission's legislative proposal could have been a little more ambitious, but at least it proposed harmonisation with the multi-year plans in Europe. The version voted in the Committee on Fisheries the vacuum of its substance: no TACs (allowable totals of catches) or quotas, abandonment of the maximum sustainable yield, replaced by the reference to biological limits, removal of the 2020 deadline on the goal of mortality and removal of the protection of juveniles. We are a long way from the objectives of the common fisheries policy. Would there be a Europe cut in half, as in the "sulphur" directive for example? A Europe with variable geometry, sometimes in the sense of sustainability, sometimes that of irresponsibility? Not only is the account not there to preserve the Mediterranean, but the inequalities thus created disintegrate the European project. I regret this for Mrs Toma-i, because I have a great deal of respect for her work, and she has worked hard, but I urge you tomorrow to vote on Amendments 93, 94, 95, 96, and 97 to bring the Mediterranean into the era of sustainability.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, rarely have I seen such a divergence of opinions, both within and beyond political groups and with the Commission, as on this topic. I think everybody here wants to see fishermen thrive, they want to see fish stocks increase, but obviously there is a dilemma in the Adriatic which needs to be addressed. When you have a situation where, as has been quoted, sardines go from 15 inches to 11 inches, that has to be explained. What’s going on? If that happened to the human race, if over a period of years people declined by four or five inches, there would be an investigation and discussion. I think Mr Kuhn gave the most balanced view when he said if there needs to be measures, the fishermen have to be helped by compensation, maybe even co—financing. A few weeks ago we brought a fishing delegation from the European Parliament to my constituency, and one of the points made by the fishermen is that they felt their voices weren’t heard enough. I think it is important to bring stakeholders, those who are on the sea every day, more into the discussion, and allow them to have their say and let them feel that they are part of the solution, not the problem.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Madam President. I, too, actually support the view that, when it comes to such important topics as restricting fishing for individual species of fish in the Adriatic, we should also listen to fishermen with all seriousness on this subject. Because fishing is a very difficult profession and fishing for these, especially small-scale fishermen, it is the only source of income. And that is why these issues are also a very sensitive subject. How, on the one hand, to strike a balance between the interests and, of course, the needs of fishermen to generate revenue and, on the other hand, to protect the fish stock of anchovies, anchovies and other fish species, which is dangerously decreasing. And here I think that long-term measures are needed, which must be based on scientific evidence, not on some short-term needs and measures, and in this way also to ensure sufficient renewable fish stocks. Otherwise, the fishermen won't have anything to hunt.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues for their interventions and valuable views. I would like to turn straightaway to some of the specific points raised by honourable Members this evening.  Let me remind you that, according to the common fisheries policy (CFP), conservation measures have to be based on best scientific advice. This does not mean that we can base our management proposal on individual scientific opinions. It means that we should use scientific advice that has been validated by the competent scientific bodies, such as the Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries (STECF) or the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) Scientific Advisory Council on the basis of a thorough review process. Such scientific advice cannot simply be dismissed because the outcome is disliked. Let me comment on the escapement strategy. The maximum sustainable yield (MSY) biomass escapement strategy is a model already used by the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES) to manage nine short—lived species, for instance, in the North Sea, the Bering Sea or the Bay of Biscay, and it has been very successful, for instance for anchovy in the Bay of Biscay. For highly valuable stocks like Adriatic sardine and anchovy, the escapement strategy allows fishing a higher fraction when the stock biomass is high and a smaller fraction when the stock is low, but always maintaining a high probability of sufficient biomass. In the long term, it should ensure higher catches while maintaining a low risk for the stock. STECF considers that the escapement procedure could be an appropriate tool to manage small pelagics in the Adriatic and to achieve the MSY objectives.  With regard to the socio—economic situation: the socio—economic situation of the fisheries sector is closely linked to the stock situation. Healthy fish go hand in hand with healthy profits. This can clearly be seen in sea basins where we have moved to FMSY and profitability has increased. This means that if we do not act or if our action is not ambitious enough, notably when we have a stock close to collapse, the socio—economic cost risks being very high. With regard to the emergency measures, given the management void for Adriatic small pelagics in 2019 and given the delay with this proposal for the multiannual plan, we proposed transitional emergency measures in the GFCM annual meeting in October. These measures establish an increased number of spatial temporal closures and a catch reduction of 5% per year until 2021. These measures will apply to the EU fleets and will be transposed in the TAC and Quota Regulation of the next three years.  Someone asked why we are moving away from existing measures. Evaluations of the existing management framework have concluded that it is ineffective and insufficient to ensure the stocks will be fished sustainably by 2020. STECF has advised that managers consider using catch or landing restrictions as a more effective management tool for small pelagic. For example, even if effort is reduced by 20%, this does not necessarily translate into a 20% reduction in catches or fishing mortality. If a vessel comes across a school of small pelagic fish, it can take a large quantity in a short amount of time. Reducing catches, on the other hand, translates directly into an equivalent reduction of fishing mortality.  I would like to make three other comments: first of all, that quotas in the Mediterranean do not work; I totally disagree with this. Quotas in the Mediterranean have worked. The only stock in the Mediterranean which managed to recover was tuna, and tuna was recovered with a quota management plan set by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT).  Another argument is that fishermen in the south should not be expected to do the same as those in the north. Why? What is the difference? The difference is compliance and the difference in the result is very significant. We have fishermen in the north – in the Baltic and in the North Sea, on the Atlantic – complying and their stocks have improved. Their profitability has improved. Quotas and management have given the result. Ten years ago, we had nine stocks at MSY. Today, thanks to management by quota, we have 54 stocks at MSY. This cannot be said of the Mediterranean, where we have 90% stock still being overfished, and where we have stocks still deteriorating and we will have almost non—existent profitability.  Finally, my last comment concerns the suggestion that I should be ashamed and that I am escaping responsibility. I do not think this is fair. I am not ashamed because I am acting in the long—term interest of the fishermen and in the long—term interest of the stocks. I would be escaping responsibility if I were ignoring scientific advice and if I were supporting overfishing. In the Mediterranean it was always said that quotas, rules and regulations do not apply. Why? Because in the Mediterranean the Member States are not alone. We have North African countries with us. So rules and quotas only apply to EU Member States, but not to North African countries. Again, this is far from the truth. Here we have two stocks which are dwindling. They only concern three of our Member States and still they do not want to manage. Why? Because they want to be different from the fishermen in the north.  Finally, let me finally remind everyone that all member countries in the Mediterranean signed the MedFish4Ever Declaration in Malta to start better protecting our Mediterranean fish stocks. May I ask if it’s going to be our own Member States who run away from this commitment. I hope that tomorrow this House will adopt a report which will set the Adriatic multiannual plan on a course very much in line with the CFP and with other multiannual plans (MAPs).

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: The Rapporteur. - Dear Chairman, I would like to take this opportunity to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution, as well as other colleagues from the Fisheries Committee and all those who participated in this debate. A big thank you also to the fishermen, their associations and the state institutions of the Adriatic Member States whose experience, data and proposals were key to the drafting of this report. So, I was mething in my backyard. Universal solutions cannot deliver the expected results and I am therefore pleased that various proposals from all relevant stakeholders have been considered in the preparation of this report. The highest quality solutions that have almost plebiscite support from fishermen and the profession have found their place in the report and it is now up to us to give them political support. The Commission's proposals, which unquestionably lead to the weakening of our fishing industry, job losses, economic strengthening of third countries at the expense of Union members and medium-term discrimination against Adriatic fishermen against the rest of the Mediterranean, are unacceptable. Citizens chose us to protect their own interests, not other people's. I am sure that this report will receive parliament's support because it is based on solutions that are in line with the GFCM recommendations that are already delivering results. The introduction of quotas is rejected by both fishermen, and the profession, and scientists, and the governments of the Member States entering the Adriatic Sea. I believe that the Commission has taken a rather rigid position here, but I also believe that there is scope to change this position once Parliament adopts this report. And, Mr. Commissioner, you're comparing this to tuna— this has nothing to do with each other. You know that as far as tuna go, quotas weren't the only thing that restored tuna. Likewise, when the quotas went up, we couldn't get all those jobs back, all those boats that the fishermen lost. So, let's not rush, let's take it slow, we have to protect the fish stock, but we also have to protect the fishermen, especially those who live on the island and the coast.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 13 November 2018.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the Commission statement on floods in Europe (2018/2928(RSP)). This debate does not give the floor on request and the blue card questions are not accepted.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, allow me to express, on behalf of the European Commission, my most sincere condolences to the families of those who have perished in the recent floods throughout Europe.  Quite tragically, these events have highlighted our vulnerability to both natural and man-made disasters. Hence the continued need for investing on the ground in better preparedness and better prevention. EU support should help regions become more resilient and more sustainable. This is the rationale behind the cohesion policy.  You know very well that under the current programming period, almost EUR 8 billion have been channelled to the climate change adaptation and risk prevention. Clearly, disaster risk management is a main focus of our policy. We invest in early warning systems, awareness-raising, flood-protection infrastructure, green infrastructures such as flood plains or green urban spaces. Besides prevention, we work on preparedness, in particular support for equipment and vehicles or training for civil protection units.  It is also important to mention the contribution of the EU’s rural development policy. Support includes investments for the restoration of damaged agriculture and forestry land and production capacity, the restoration of rural infrastructure and preventive actions and risk-management tools for farmers.  But building prevention and resilience is a very complex process which entails a long lasting match between public investment and the reality on the ground. This is why, following the disasters of last year, the Commission adopted the so-called ‘risk EU package’, which included a screening of all relevant operational programmes. The aim here was to see whether there were any gaps in the support we provided.  The good news is that the current priorities in our programmes already match very closely with the highest risk that Member States have identified themselves in their national risk assessments. This is partly thanks to our funding.   More generally, we offer flexibility in our programmes. This means amendments can be proposed and swiftly agreed to shift resources towards areas that are most in need. So, if changes are necessary, they can still be made under the current funding period. The Commission is also supporting Member States in the implementation of the Floods Directive and will publish by the beginning of next year, an assessment for the first flood risk management plans prepared by the Member States under this directive. This mapping will allow adequate and coordinating measures to reduce flood risk. Besides a long-term approach to natural disasters, there is, of course, an emergency dimension. The Commission’s risk EU package, which I just mentioned, was also introduced to upgrade the EU’s emergency response, notably by revising the European Union’s civil protection mechanism put in place in 2001 to provide external assistance to Member States or a third country. It goes without saying that the Commission stands ready to help any affected country through this mechanism. Last, but not least, we have the EU Solidarity Fund, directly managed by my services. The European Union Solidarity Fund is pivotal as it complements rapid-response measures helping regions and countries to restore essential infrastructure, ensure continuity of public services, assist populations and protect cultural heritage. The Commission’s services are currently working hand-in-hand with the Italian and Austrian authorities who are considering applying for solidarity assistance after the recent floods. As always, we stand ready to help them throughout the process. Thank you for your attention and I am looking forward to our debate.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: I would also like to make it clear that there is only one round of speeches by the political groups in this debate, not on request and no blue card questions.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Yes, indeed, in the last few days of October and the first days of November, a storm has passed over the whole of Europe, and this has also affected the Alpine region and the Italian Alpine region in particular. In my region, in South Tyrol, in Trentino, especially in the particularly affected Belluno, there has been rain over the day, there has been flooding and wind gusts of up to 200 kilometres per hour have bent over entire forests. Millions of cubic metres of wood are now lying and need to be reworked. In my region alone, 1.1 million cubic metres of wood are affected. This is particularly tragic because it is also a Unesco World Heritage Site, with wounds that will be visible for decades to come. The forests do not grow overnight. But what is particularly tragic is that people have also died: in total, 32 people have died in Italy – it was also southern Italy, the region of Sicily in particular. In my region, a volunteer firefighter who tried to help people at night has died in this work for his fellow human beings, which I find particularly tragic. Quindi, penso che sia bene che facciamo questo dibattito oggi, anche per mostrare la nostra solidariet, e condivido in pieno quello che lei, signora Commissario, ha detto appena adesso. Ma la solidariet deve diventare concreta. Certo che serve anche la prevenzione, per la gente colpita della prevenzione in questo momento ha poco vantaggio, serve aiuto, serve l'aiuto concreto.  Quindi dobbiamo fare di tutto affinché si apra il Fondo di solidariet. Viviamo in Italia in un momento dove a volte mi sembra che l'Unione europea viene resa responsabile per tutto. L'Unione europea responsabile per le difficolt economiche del paese, per le infrastrutture che crollano e per i flussi migratori. Viene dipinto un quadro molto buio dell'Unione europea.  Quindi questa anche un'occasione per noi. Un'occasione per far capire agli italiani e alla popolazione italiana che esiste l'Unione europea che aiuta, l'Unione europea solidale, l'Unione europea che in un momento di difficolt sta dalla parte della gente, e quindi dobbiamo sfruttare questa occasione. Dobbiamo veramente cercare di far presto, di dare anche una risposta alla richiesta del governo italiano, che ha dichiarato lo stato di calamit nazionale, affinché ci siano le possibilit di aiuto del Fondo di solidariet europeo e che ci siano anche presto.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for this debate, which we had, moreover, strongly requested, on the recent floods in Italy, southern Europe and, unfortunately, in my own land, Sicily, where in just 24 hours half the rain of a whole year fell and the tragedy was the size of 12 deaths and hundreds and hundreds of millions of euros in damage and infrastructure and crops.  Thank you for your condolences and solidarity, which I will extend to the families of the victims of an absurd tragedy in a hell of water, mud, carelessness and disinterest. You think the body of the last missing man, a young doctor on his way to work, was recovered only four days ago. In just over ten years, natural disasters have cost the European Union around EUR 100 billion. We are talking about a third of the entire budget that the Union devotes to cohesion policies. It is clear that, in the face of massive climate change, if damage is to be limited, preventive action must be increased and cohesion policy must be the instrument for supporting them in addition to the Solidarity Fund.  Local and regional authorities benefiting from cohesion measures are also the first to deal with the impacts of disasters. Disaster prevention is one of the central axes of regional development, and it is clear that cohesion must become the main source of funding for the prevention and fight against climate change, if we consider that, according to ispra data, within a century the increase in the average temperature in Italy could even exceed two degrees.  Prevention measures and interventions are left to the Member States of the European Union. It is up to them to invest and spend on infrastructure policies, but states and regions often forget to do so or cannot sustain the necessary investment. So, Commissioner, we really need the European Union's intervention now, because the EUR 114 billion devoted to climate change response measures, which is serving our budget, is no longer needed.  We need, in the face of a huge disaster, as we saw in my land only ten days ago, of all concrete solidarity, of aid, support, of funds, of compensation for those who, in addition to life, have even lost what was their work, their daily lives. It is precisely in these situations that the European Union must make its citizens perceive their presence and their usefulness, excuse me.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I greet the Commissioner, who I am very pleased to see, because in the few minutes, in the few seconds we have, I would like to focus on what has happened in southern Europe over the past few days and I would like to focus in particular on one province, the mountain province par excellence: the province of Belluno, the province of the Dolomites, to understand each other as Europeans. You see, such serious events have happened there that we felt a duty to move as a Venetian community. Thousands of volunteers have arrived, 100 000 hectares of forests have fallen, forests that have always been protected, Commissioner. There is a model there that is called "the rules", which have protected that extraordinary territory that is a very beautiful but very difficult territory. We also made some mistakes there. The first mistake we made when we decided to pass the energy by air through wires and poles. This led to the great disaster: thousands and thousands of utilities cancelled for days, people in great difficulty. And all this because in past years we have not wanted to spend a few extra money to bury those cables.  I must thank Mr De Carlo, as well as mayor of a community in the province of Belluno, because he accompanied me and made me understand how important it is. I have already run out of time, but I would like to conclude with three very very important facts. You see, St. Mark's Basilica has been totally submerged. Debris and sludge killed 80 % of clams grown in the Venetian valleys. Above all, however, I believe that the Solidarity Fund should be activated yesterday not tomorrow. That is why I strongly call for the Solidarity Fund to be set up immediately for a territory so damaged by a catastrophic event.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Climate change is making extreme natural phenomena more frequent. Last year, my country Lithuania suffered from persistent heavy rains and floods. This year, the country was devastated by drought. For two consecutive years, our agriculture has been plagued by emergencies. The European Union has allocated twenty-six million euro to Lithuania for compensation. However, this represents only six per cent of the direct damage suffered. In fact, the money-free damage is such that 19% of farms and cows have left production in the last year and a half alone. To this, farmers in the Baltic states receive the lowest direct payments from the European Union. Therefore, it finds itself in an even more difficult situation. In my hands, the appeal of The Baltic MEPs to the harmonisation of payments to our farmers in the next financial period. I hope that both you, colleagues and the Commissioner, the Members of the Council, will agree that Europe must take responsibility for all its farmers equally and that payments must be equalised for the next period.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, according to data from the 2018 report of the Institute of Environmental Protection, 2 million inhabitants in Italy are exposed to high flood risk and 6 million to medium-risk. 91 % of Italian municipalities are at combined risk for floods and landslides. And even more so, in view of the tragic events and the victims that we have mourned in recent weeks, it is clear that hydrogeological rehabilitation is the real and absolute priority for Italy. It should be for the Italian Government, it should be for the European Union, and instead we continue to hear about budgetary constraints, fiscal compacts, TAPs, high-quality trains, major useless and harmful works that drain enormous resources.  Again, the government continues the tradition of Craxi and Berlusconi with a new building amnesty. On the contrary, resources would be needed, first and foremost for those municipalities that are engaged in the detection of building abuses and that instead lack the essential structures for the application of laws against abuse. Municipalities which, as a result of budget cuts and constraints, have been deprived of resources, powers and means to tackle a very serious problem. In Sicily, in Casteldaccia, a whole family lost their lives because it was not possible to complete the process of demolishing a building built by a river and certified as abusive for years. Damage also multiplies due to the thirst for continuous profit. In the Belluno region destroyed by the flood at the end of October, Terna S.p.a. builds overhead power lines with pygles 60 meters high in places subject to landscape constraint and community interest and, as we can see, at risk of flooding. Those slits should be interned. We need a new season of public investment, we need structural resources, not extraordinary funds.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the League, I would like to express my solidarity with all the citizens who have been victims of the terrible wave of bad weather in recent weeks. First of all I want to thank civil protection and the thousands of volunteers who are helping our people.  Eleven Italian regions, especially veneto and the whole of the North East, have been brought to their knees by floods, whirlwinds, storms, which have wiped out houses, roads, woods, beaches and human lives. According to initial estimates, the damage budgets are very heavy. Over EUR 1 billion in Veneto, my region; over EUR 500 million, in Friuli Venezia Giulia; EUR 250 million in Trentino Alto Adige, hundreds and hundreds of millions in Liguria, Lazio, Sicily and the rest of Italy. Faced with this disaster, our citizens need to have urgently available all the resources that Europe can provide, first and then the European Solidarity Fund, which must be disbursed as quickly as possible. We ask Europe for maximum cooperation to help the Venetians, friulians and all Italians who have been affected by the bad weather and who are already working to rebuild our countries.  We do not want Europe's alms, because our people are used to working, pulling up their sleeves and doing it themselves. In Brussels we are only asking for what is ours, which is the Italians. Every year they have given millions of EUROS that have not been returned to our country. We want our money back, other than budgetary constraints and austerity. We want to spend our money on rebuilding our countries, on secureing our territory and on helping our citizens who have lost everything. For once, I call for Europe to show real solidarity and to think of our citizens, not the spread or the interests of the banks.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, a year after the floods in Mandra, 160 areas in Greece are at risk for new flooding, while in both Mati and other areas the inhabitants are unsymed after the fires. In our question, the Commission fully covers the research it has funded and which has come to the provocative conclusion that, while unfair, it is more cost-effective to protect wealthy families or factories than to protect the poor, since justice, it says, is not included in the cost-benefit analysis. Because flood defences have no tolls, tickets, customers "head to head" or sales "with the piece". That is why they are not preferred and prioritised, while at the same time no compensation is provided for those affected by the Solidarity Fund themselves, with its known elusive limits. Moreover, the Commission, under the responsibility of the government, does not provide compensation for the recent floods in Central Greece, Evia and the Peloponnese either. This was answered by the Commission to a question from meps from the Communist Party of Greece. The people must resolutely oppose the criterion of capitalist gain and by fighting for immediate compensation at 100% for those affected and substantial relief and prevention measures.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, once again, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to thank you all for sharing your views and for voicing your concerns for the regions and the people that have been deeply affected by the recent floods. Of course, this is not about an ordinary file; it is about people who have lost their loved ones and some of them who have lost everything. To them, I think, we have to have the same message, together: that Europe cares, that Europe is here to help. It is our common job. You know, of course, that I am in charge of Cohesion Policy, and I think Cohesion Policy has in its very essence the European solidarity. The European Union as a whole has benefited each time about European solidarity. So it’s quite natural, when floods occur, that the European Union’s mission – European Union added value – lies by the side of the victims in the damaged regions, not only on the ground but also in the air. Last week, for example, after the request from the Italian authorities, the European Commission mobilised the Copernicus emergency satellite. I think close to 50 highly-detailed satellite maps were provided to assess the damage to the affected regions. I am sorry to say, but it’s not fair to say that Europe didn’t show solidarity to Italy. Italy is the first country that benefited in the last year by the Solidarity Fund. I would like to remind you about our solidarity at the time of the earthquakes. I was there on the ground. President Juncker was there on the ground, and on the emergency procedures we released EUR 1.2 billion for the four regions affected by the earthquake in Italy. So let’s not be populist. We are waiting now for the assessment of the damage because we cannot do the assessment of the damage. It’s part of the job of the Italian government. We are working hand in hand, but we cannot assess the damage when we don’t know how much. And I would like to tell you something: you in the European Parliament and in the Council made the regulation of the Solidarity Fund, and it was not written in the regulation how we measure the life of one person. You put in the regulation – the European Parliament – that we assess only economic damage. It’s tragic that we don’t compensate, and do you want to do for the next programing period this idea to compensate the families who lose the life of their loved one? But we don’t have in the regulations something like that now, so we assess only economic damages and we waiting for the Italian government to give us the assessment. We are also open to shift or change operational programmes on the request of the Italian government. I am in direct contact with Madam Lezzi, with the Minister. They are working hard with the local administration because it is not easy to evaluate the damage. But Europe is here, and we are here day by night to help, and we were there during the earthquake. So I think it’s very easy to blame the European Commission. But look also at what is happening in local and regional policy, because in some regions – not even now – the money that we have released last year in Italy didn’t reach the people affected by the earthquake. I would like just to say that we have large interventions in Europe – in Madeira, in Greece. You know very well that last year we were in contact in Greece, in Evia. We showed solidarity but it was the same problem: that we don’t have how to measure the lives and it was not an economical area there in Greece, so Greece didn’t qualify to apply for the Solidarity Fund, unfortunately, but we compensate by more EU funds for the Attica region. I think we need to show to the people how much and strong the response in the European Union is needed to such tragic circumstances. But we have to be fair: to be fair that we have shared management and shared responsibilities. Of course we are coming with the emergency response. We come also with the Solidarity Fund, which is not an emergency tool; it compensates for the day one. But at the same time it is also the responsibility of the government and the local authorities, for which I have full sympathies in such moments. So let’s face things very clearly: things will not get better. Unfortunately the effects of climate change are getting harsher, and we will certainly continue to pay the price of decades of unsustainable land and country planning. We need to put all our efforts, all our ideas in prevention and resilience-building to mitigate the effects not only of floods but also, as I said, of forest fires, earthquakes, coastal erosion and drought. Europe must keep strong on emergency response. It’s a matter of saving and preserving lives, as I said, but it’s also a long-distance run that will go beyond the many multiannual financial frameworks to come. It starts now by giving our Union the capacity to pave the way for a sustainable future. Thank you very much and, as always, you can rely on us. We are waiting for the assessment of the damages from the governments affected and we are ready to do all the necessary changes for all the emergency bases, because we know how important it is to be here and to show solidarity.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. – The change in the pattern – frequency and volume – of devastating floods worldwide is a clear consequence of climate change. Increasingly frequent flooding, with huge amounts of water flowing down our rivers, is regularly followed by extremely hot and dry periods. Adapting to extreme weather events is in humanity's primary interest. In view of this, it is particularly important to manage life-a life water much more consciously. We need to develop and implement ecologically conscious solutions that are naturally fit, where we can channel the huge excess water that we draw from flooding and use it to alleviate water scarcity during drought. Sustainable management of the body of water generated after flooding should aim to provide as wide a range of ecological services as possible.  The other fact about the floods, which I would like to draw your attention to, is the latest IPCC publication that it is still possible to keep the temperature rise below 1.5C! This is a huge chance for humanity to avoid, or at least reduce, the already "priced" losses and costs that we have written off in the face of climate change. It is imperative for all governments, and for all people, to take the necessary steps within the limits of their own possibilities for our children to inherit a liveable planet. Where daily life is characterised not by devastating floods and famine-causing droughts, but by moderate prosperity and peace.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the József Nagy report on minimum standards for minorities in the EU (2018/2036(INI)) (A8-0353/2018).

name: József NAGY
text: I'm not going to do that – It is not for nothing that I still use my mother tongue today, because, among other things, I am about to present to you my report on the rights of the mother tongue. The European Union's motto is 'United in Diversity', which emphasises respect for diversity as one of the fundamental values of the European Union. Minority rights are not only important for minorities, they are in the interests of all of us. We are well known that the deregard for minority rights leads to hatred, ethnic conflicts and even wars. Yes, here on our democratic continent, we have seen more ethnic carnage and war in the last 20 years, starting with the Balkans and, hopefully, ending with Ukraine. The tragic police action and manslaughter against the Greek minority in Macedonia the other day has also been insted by ethnic tensions. A well-functioning, strong democracy recognises this and does its best to maintain peace and security. The protection of the rights of minorities is a means of doing so. I therefore consider the institution of the EU Minimum Minority Law to be primarily a peace project, which also benefits the majority nations. Today, nearly 40 million citizens in Europe consider themselves to belong to national or linguistic and cultural minorities. And rightly so, these 40 million people want to preserve their traditions and cultural identity. EU Member States generally provide a high level of legal security and comfort to minorities in their territory and the legal framework for this has been developed in most Member States. Unfortunately, EU practice and access to services in this direction are no longer so ideal, and unfortunately it is often the case that, without the rights declared in international conventions, ethnic discrimination is used to inst cause tensions between citizens and the nationality card is also used to gain political power. To prevent these abuses, I have prepared this report, which is in order to create a accountable European minimum minority law. Of course, Member States continue to define their own minorities on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity. The three pillars of my report and the proposed minimum law are the EU-wide guarantee of education, culture and language rights. Because I believe that the European Union is capable of legislating in these three areas. We have respected the exclusive powers of the Member States, the political rights: the definition of territorial self-government and electoral rights remains the responsibility of the Member States. I am particularly interested in discrimination, hate crimes and hate speech and the means of combating them, which is in the interest of all of us. My aim is to give people belonging to minorities the courage to exercise their basic cultural and linguistic rights in their homes and on the streets, anywhere in Europe, without fear. My aim is to ensure that education in minority languages is accepted and of a high standard throughout Europe, forming bridges between the cultures of the majority and the cultures of the minority, knowing, accepting and supporting each other. The Treaty of the European Union states that 'the Union respects its own cultural and linguistic diversity and ensures the preservation and further enhancement of Europe's cultural heritage'. If our real aim is to preserve our European culture and pass it on to future generations, then we also have a duty to ensure the rights of minorities! I call on my fellow Members to support my report and the Commission to send its legislative proposal for EU minimum legislation as soon as possible.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: – First of all, I would like to thank my fellow Member Jozsef Nagy for drafting this report, as this is another step towards a single protection of minorities at EU level. As rapporteur for the Commission's opinion on this report, I am very pleased that the topic of education and culture in the mother tongue and the use of the mother tongue have been prominently included in the report in all areas of life. Mother tongue education is essential for the enforcement of language rights and Member States should therefore be encouraged to give regional and national minorities an adequate opportunity to learn their mother tongue and to learn their mother tongue at all levels of education in the regions in which they live. The right to education is the fundamental right of all people, and education in the mother tongue plays a key role in preserving identity and culture. The report also states that the EU should focus more on the legal protection of national, regional and linguistic minorities in its territory, since, although minority rights are enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and a number of international documents, there is no single legislative mechanism for the protection of minorities.  I am therefore pleased that parliament's report has included parliament's call on the European Commission to submit a legislative proposal in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, and we look forward to it!

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, it has never been true that democracy consists only, and simply, of the rule of majority. No. Democracy consists essentially of the protection of the minority, and also of ensuring the role of the opposition; but above all, in respecting the sovereignty of the individual in the enjoyment of his fundamental rights. And that is exactly what Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union says. And if the European Union has taken on the so-called 'Copenhagen dilemma' to try to fill the mandate of commitment to the rule of law, democracy, respect for fundamental rights and judicial protection by an independent judiciary, it must also come to a structured and articulated mechanism for the protection of minorities in the European Union. Because this protection is frankly in reverse with the advancement of the discourse of discrimination and its practice, of hate speech and its practice, and with the policy of exclusion and its practice, which is ramping in a good number of Member States in an alarming and threatening way for the founding values of the Union. That is why this resolution is important. It is important that we be able to build an articulated mechanism for the protection of minorities that responds to this setback, to this regression of the democratic quality of the constitutional state that denies the founding values of the Union.

name: Notis MARIAS

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Madam President, let me first point out that I very much honour the rapporteur, Mr Nagy, and appreciate his activities. text: – Mr President, respect for the rights of minorities is the duty of every civilised country.
