name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to thank you for putting this important issue of minority rights in the European Union on the agenda of the European Parliament.  One of the key assets of the European Union is diversity: diversity of languages, cultures, traditions, religions and origins. After all, as has been said here, our motto is ‘united in diversity’. Besides, our Union rests on the values of human dignity, equality, the rule of law and human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. Any discrimination against national minorities is explicitly prohibited under Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  However, as noted in your report, the European Union and the Commission have no overall competence to rule on the protection of national minorities. These questions fall under the sole responsibility of the Member States, which have an obligation to guarantee minorities the full enjoyment of their human rights. In that respect, the Commission closely monitors the transposition of the relevant EU legal framework. This includes the Race Equality Directive, the Employment Equality Directive, the Framework Decision on combating racism and xenophobia by means of criminal law, the EU free movement acquis and the Audiovisual Media Services Directive. To extend the current anti-discrimination legislation, the Commission proposed, ten years ago already, the Horizontal Equality Directive.  I take this opportunity to call on all Member States to adopt this proposal, which will benefit many while disadvantaging nobody. We are also doing substantial work to tackle discrimination, racism and xenophobia. We have a High Level Group on Non-Discrimination, Equality and Diversity, a Group on Racism and Xenophobia and the National Roma Contact Points network. All this work brings together representatives from Member States to exchange good practices and put non-discrimination, hate speech and hate crime on their national agendas. The Commission is also promoting best practices regarding the democratic participation of underrepresented groups. This topic will be part of the discussion at the Annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights, dedicated this year to democracy. Promoting minority languages is also an important driver for social and economic inclusion. The Commission has recently adopted a proposal for a Council recommendation on improving the teaching and learning of languages by taking the multitude of linguistic realities into account. We also have the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme, the Erasmus Programme and the Creative Europe programme. Besides, the Commission raises awareness on the importance of language learning through public events like the European Day of Languages or the national awards of the European Language Label for innovative learning projects.  Let me conclude by emphasising that the Commission strives – and will continue to do so under the next financial framework – to ensure that fundamental rights – and in particular the right to non-discrimination – are respected when EU law is implemented. Where we cannot propose legislation, we will use a soft law instrument, exchange of best practices and funding to help promote the rights of minorities.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I'm closing the agenda. The vote will take place on Tuesday 13 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Around 8% of European Union citizens belong to national and ethnic minorities and nearly 10% speak regional or minority language. Nevertheless, there are no common EU standards and definitions on minority rights in the Union. This is all the more important because persistent harassment, discrimination and violence deprive citizens of the full enjoyment of fundamental rights and freedoms and hinder their equal participation in society.  In recent years, we have seen far-right forces promote xenophobic violence and hate speech. There is an increase in hate crimes and an increase in racist, xenophobic or religiously motivated hate speech. Given that in an increasing number of Member States the far right is gaining in popularity, it can be assumed that discrimination against minorities is likely to increase.  The union's fundamental problem is that it does not have the instruments to enforce respect for the rights of minorities from the Member States. This area should therefore be the subject of constant monitoring and dialogue within Parliament, the Commission and the Council. It is a good idea to establish a body within the existing Commission structures responsible for the recognition and protection of minorities in the Union. This would at least help to monitor the situation in the Member States until common rules are established defining the minority and its rights.

name: Soraya POST
text: in writing. – There is a well-known saying: ‘A country should be judged on the basis of how it treats its minorities’. This sentence can also be applied to the EU, where we cannot be proud of ourselves yet. The commonly set values in our Treaties demand respect for human rights and human dignity, equality and non-discrimination, also concerning the rights of minorities; however, reports by the EU Fundamental Rights Agency (FRA), NGOs and watchdog organisations show us a very sad reality. Our work is not done until we safeguard that people belonging to minorities can learn and use their language without limitations, can practice their traditions without fear, can live without being deprived of their rights and discriminated against in all spheres of life, and can participate in policymaking and decision-making processes. To achieve this, those in power have to take equal responsibility for people belonging to minority groups; they have to actively fight all forms of discrimination, condemn and impose sanctions for hate speech and hate crime, and they have to ensure minorities’ representatives participate in decision-making. Furthermore, they have to raise mainstream society’s awareness of the history of minority groups and mark their commemoration days.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – It is understandable and timely that the European Parliament call on the European Commission to take action to guarantee the rights of national minorities in the European Union. This is particularly true in the face of the EU's growing wave of radical political forces. There are also really vulnerable ethnic communities, such as the Roma, who, without their own state and being scattered around different countries, are completely dependent on the policies of their national minorities. The focus on them at Community level would therefore be a significant contribution to maintaining national identity, language and culture. As an MEP myself, I am making every effort in my own Member State to make the Roma national community as much as possible able to uphold its language. I therefore see this report as a good impetus for the affairs of the Roma minority in the context of the EU as a whole. Another important highlight of the report is the call for centralised monitoring of the implementation of the rights of national minorities across the EU. Such objective monitoring would prevent third countries with their own, not always friendly objectives, from speculating on the situation of national minorities in the EU.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: in writing. – In almost every country of the Union there are important communities made up of national minorities of other states. Whether these minorities existed historically in a certain geographical area, or formed as a result of labour migration, I firmly believe that our duty, all of them, is to give all these people rights at least at some level. Romania is one of the countries that stands out at European level and is given an example in this respect by the way in which it has intended to ensure a standard for national minorities, from the right to education in the mother tongue to the right to have bilingual inscriptions or to address public authorities in their native language in communities inhabited by national minorities in a certain percentage of the total population. Romanians, in turn, form large communities in other European Union states. In this context, I consider it appropriate to have a constructive discussion in the European Parliament about ensuring minimum standards for minorities, not only for the benefit of Romanians who have chosen to work in other countries, but for the benefit of all those who have found a place of their own in a country other than their native country.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on bogdan brunon wenta's report on "Digitalisation for Development: Poverty Reduction through Technology" (2018/2083(INI)) (A8-0338/2018). This and the previous theme overlap ownership. The latest reports clearly show that poverty and being a minority overlap in many cases. This is why it was important for the European Union to find digital tools to fight poverty eradication.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, let me start by thanking all shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation on this report outlining the impact of technology and digitisation in developing countries. I welcome the Commission strategy on mainstreaming digitisation into EU development policy announced last year, and EU Commissioner Mariya Gabriel’s statement that Europe is dedicated to helping Africa build a single digital market. We managed to prepare in our committee a very comprehensive text addressing the main opportunities and challenges that digitisation brings to development cooperation and humanitarian action.  Nelson Mandela said that communication technologies have transformed the way people live and the manner in which countries develop. They have the potential to enable us to solve many of the critical problems confronting us. If this potential is to be realised then we must find ways of turning these technologies into a resource for all people, despite the challenges they face within their communities.  What does it mean? Digital technologies have huge potential in terms of reducing poverty, increasing the competitiveness of the economy and creating employment opportunities. Whereas digitisation is rapidly growing globally our partners from developing countries continue to lag behind, losing the opportunity to fully utilise their human capital towards the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. According to the 2016 World Development Report on Digital Dividends, six billion people lack access to high-speed internet and four billion still have no internet access at all. At a time when digitisation is growing fast, this lack of access is a major challenge to development as it continues to widen gaps and inequalities in the world. At the same time, a huge increase in mobile services is securing across the planet and the numbers of mobile users are now surpassing the numbers of people having access to electricity, sanitation or clean water. Digitisation can be a powerful development tool in a number of policy areas such as governance, education, health, gender equality, economic growth and agriculture. In order for it to be effective, bridging the digital divide has to be mainstreamed into every other policy area in accordance with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. In order to realise these goals, both developing countries and developed countries, as well as all actors – both public and private – need to maximise and join their efforts.  In the European Consensus on Development which is a crucial document on development policy of the EU and its Member States, we can find the bold statement that they will continue to support information and communication technologies in developing countries as powerful enablers of inclusive growth and sustainable development. Special attention has been given to supporting digital literacy and skills to empower people, especially women, and people in vulnerable and marginalised situations to promote social inclusion and to facilitate the participation in democratic governance and the digital economy.  We are all aware of the fact that in this area of developing cooperation, public funding will not be sufficient for a truly transformative digitalisation process. For this very reason, there is a need for public-private cooperation based on development principles.  The private sector needs to get involved and play a role through its expertise and innovation know-how. I am convinced that the substantial support from the EU, international actors and both public and private sectors, will allow us to step up the process of bridging the digital divide with a strong commitment to this process from the developing countries.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank my colleague Bogdan Wenta very much for this report. He pointed out that, unfortunately, even within the European Union, not all Member States are the same on digitisation. But this is even more true for developing countries. Sub-Saharan Africa, for example, is the worst off in terms of digitalisation and internet accessibility. It is in these development areas that digitalisation represents a great opportunity for economic and social development. Individual Member States should therefore adopt this area of digitalisation in their national development cooperation strategies. Many areas are doing very well, there is no problem with the number of mobile phones or the Internet, but it is very geographically unbalanced, and here we need to make a change. I would like to draw attention to the protection against the dangers of the misuse of personal data, the misuse of the Internet for the spread of radicalism. This, too, is a matter in which the European Union can set a good example.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we live in the digital age, an age that has generated incredible speed in the way we learn or distribute information. Digitalisation has brought with it important opportunities, especially in the way we have access to new information, the short time it takes to access it, but also in the way we use this information to make our daily lives easier. Poverty is one of the direct consequences of lack of information. Whether we are talking about the literacy rate in a particular area or access to higher education, digitalisation brings with it a number of advantages. Digitalisation also means the development of public utility applications that can be used by local public administrations for the benefit of citizens. Digitalisation means a huge opportunity for today's young people: learning a programming language, but even learning basic digital skills gives an extra chance to those who lean into this field - information and communication technology. Young people from anywhere and from any social environment can have this success.  In short, digitalisation brings with it the opportunity for an extra chance to get a job, benefits for communities and, ultimately, the possibility of reducing poverty through access to information and knowledge.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we are talking about digitisation, which must be put at the service of development to reduce poverty through the use of technology. But the question is, what do we mean by 'development'? Will we have growth for whom, for what interests, in what direction and in what way? Will we have growth with a fair distribution of wealth and fairness? Or will we have growth just to make the rich richer and the poor poorer? And, at the same time, the countries of the European north, the developed countries, moving forward and the developing countries being left behind? So it is primarily a matter of choice.  Secondly, technologies are not socially neutral. They can be used towards over-exploitation of developing countries. But if the right political choices are made, they can be put at the service of developing countries themselves, so that these countries can reap the fruits of their own development and exploit their own wealth.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes this report and I would like to thank rapporteur Wenta and the Committee on Development (DEVE) for their work. Digitalisation is a key factor for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, and of course it provides cost-effective solutions to development needs by creating high—quality jobs and sustainable growth. It is also an effective instrument to address challenges such as social exclusion and inequality, cybersecurity, data protection and governance.  In May 2017, the Commission services put forward a new Digital4Development strategic approach, the so-called D4D, which outlines four priority areas for future EU interventions: access to open, affordable and secure broadband connectivity and digital infrastructure; digital literacy skills; digital for growth, entrepreneurship and job creation; and digital technologies as an enabler. The D4D approach has gained momentum. It is now reflected in the European Consensus on Development and in the Communication on a new Africa—Europe alliance for sustainable investment in jobs. More generally, under the current period, the Commission’s development policy has put a strong emphasis on digitalisation. Last year alone, over EUR 100 million were invested in projects covering mostly regional digital infrastructure. Besides, over EUR 200 million are being invested to support a new initiative in key thematic areas: energy, governance, education, health and agriculture.  We also have the European Union External Investment Plan adopted in September 2017, which can support digital solutions for local needs. Thanks to its financial arm – the European Fund for Sustainable Development – it helps secure private investment. So far, two projects have been selected for a total of EUR 175 million.  Lastly, the European Union, in collaboration with the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, is preparing the first Africa e—commerce week in December. The objective is to trigger policy harmonisation for an African single digital market and to engage with the local private sector. Now, looking towards the future, the Commission will continue in the context of the next Multiannual Financial Framework to support developments through ambitious digital policies, with a strong focus on youth. We will also prioritise digital education skills and technical and vocational training to ensure the labour offer matches market demand. We also wish to strengthen our political dialogue with partner countries and regional organisations – in particular the African Union – to promote good governance and an investment-friendly climate. We will also strengthen the actions of our EU delegations, notably by setting up a network of contact points on D4D. To conclude, in the light of our discussion, we can all agree that we have reached a pivotal moment. Together with the EU Member States, the European financial institutions, the private sector and civil society, we have the opportunity to truly influence the impact of digital transformation worldwide. In this endeavour, the Commission is confident that the European Parliament will keep momentum and remain a strong partner. Thank you for your attention. I would also like to congratulate you, rapporteur, on being elected Mayor – I wish you good luck and a lot of success, for the benefit of the citizens of your city.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I'm closing the agenda. The vote will take place on Tuesday 13 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – Digitalisation today is the key to sustainable development and affects all segments of people's lives. Technological divisions leading to social inequality should be bridged and internet access to a wide mass should be provided so that all people are equally informed and able to communicate with each other. Technological progress and digitalisation must be the essence of all development policies. Involving new people in decision-making and information sharing will help the world develop and progress.  One solution that would bridge the digital divide is the European Consensus on Development, which clearly defines the commitment, and states that the EU and the Member States will continue to support ICT in developing countries as elements enabling inclusive growth and sustainable development and will work to facilitate the deployment of digital solutions and promote the use of digital technologies in a number of priority areas. Investing in digitalisation can be a powerful driver of growth in these countries, but it is essential that such investment reaches everyone, regardless of gender, geographical affiliation or economic status.  With better infrastructure and improved internet access, the aim is to create an energy grid, reduce taxes on digital products and services and promote competition. I believe that digitalisation will greatly contribute to tackling world poverty and inequality in society.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report on EU development aid in the field of education prepared by Vincent Peillon on behalf of the Committee on Development (2018/2081(INI)) (A8-0327/2018).

name: Vincent PEILLON
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank the colleagues in the Committee on Development, and in particular the shadow rapporteurs. The work we have done together has allowed us to obtain a unanimous vote in committee, minus one abstention. I hope that this unity will be met tomorrow, because it will give strength to Parliament's position. All the more so since this unity was done not to the detriment, but to the service of strong, clear and precise positions.  The first aim of this report is to put education back at the heart of development policies.  Education is more than education. Quoted many times this evening, it is of course a goal in itself because it conditions progress in many areas: health, democracy, economic development, gender equality. Essential and demanding, in the case of a complex and long-term policy, education has been neglected. At the global level, as at the European Union level, aid fell between 2009 and 2015. It rose from 11% of the EU's total aid to 7.5%, and globally from 8.3% to 6.2%. This is completely at odds with the stated objectives. Of course, efforts have been made since 2016, they deserve to be praised. But they are not enough to catch up. They must therefore not only be pursued in the long term, but they must also be greatly amplified. To do this, we need to make financial commitments and spend 15% of our development assistance on education by 2030. Specific targets must be included in the next multi-year financial framework. At the same time, the Commission must now consider how to achieve development objective 4 and define a strategy to achieve it. It is to do so in a new communication, which will replace its last text of 2002, updated with a working paper in 2010. Education must therefore be made a priority for development policies. To be effective, clear priorities must be set. That is what the Development Committee has done. We make choices. We set two priorities. The first is to ensure free and quality basic education for all. I am talking about basic education, which has been hit hard by the credit cuts. Basic and inclusive education is the 12-year primary and secondary education cycle and must be free of charge. We must therefore support public education and not commercial private institutions that seek to take advantage of the education market, as they would in any other market. That's the first priority. The second is to strengthen our support for the least developed countries, not only because they are obviously the ones who need it most, but also because that is where aid is most effective. These two priorities are not the priorities we are pursuing today, so we need to rectify that. The EU and Member States must spend at least 50% of their aid on basic education by 2030 and at least 40% of their aid, still by 2030, to the least developed countries. So these are clear and specific objectives, priorities assumed. Finally, it must be more effective, it is not enough just to put more money, it is not just enough to meet clear priorities, it must be implemented effectively. We need reliable, accurate and independent assessment instruments.  Member States' assistance must be combined, coordinated with delegations or joint programming. We also want our partners to take ownership of these policies, and that is why we have chosen to focus on budget support. Finally, only one-third of aid for education comes from multilateral organizations, compared to two-thirds in the health sector. There is a need to strengthen the participation of multilateral organizations, and in particular the global partnership for education. We now have a concise and clear report, which sets out political priorities, methods to be preferred and numerical objectives. I hope that this text will be adopted tomorrow by the largest majority of Parliament, so that it can be useful to all those involved in education.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to stress that reducing the resources spent on education is definitely a bad trend that needs to be reversed. I agree with the proposal to increase the funding ratio in this sector and consider it a step in the right direction. In addition to the priorities set out in the Committee on Development's proposal, I would like to highlight one more fact, namely the fundamental and neglected importance of tertiary education. This education is really important for the development of any region, not only the affected region, but the more the affected. Without quality universities, particularly poorer regions will not be able to cope with the brain drain, as these brains will, of course, be seeded in places with better education. If we do not invest in tertiary education, European universities will not be attractive to the work of researchers, which may mean that Europe will no longer be able to compete with the very global players in the field of technological development. I would like to stress that we are already following this trend and it is really necessary to stand up to this trend and prevent it from deepening.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I support this report on The European Union's development aid in the field of education. After all, education is a fundamental human right, education is the key to personal success, and it is also the best tool in the fight against poverty. We must therefore strive to ensure that all children have access to education, especially where they do not yet have it, where it is not of good quality, where children cannot be educated, which is Africa in particular. I also support the objective of increasing the share of each Member State in investment in teaching and education in development cooperation by ten percent by 2024 or by 15% by 2030. They're the right indicators. There is much talk that it is precisely in the fight against migration that we must help in the countries of origin, and investment in education here would be the best tool. I would also like to recall the remote adoption programme to which many citizens contribute.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, I would like to draw attention to the work of Dr Björn Haβler from the University of Cambridge, who I had the pleasure of speaking to last week at a meeting facilitated by the Humanitarian Centre. We discussed improving educational outcomes in sub-Saharan Africa, where many schools are places of crowded classrooms staffed by overworked, low-paid and often under-qualified teachers. Dr Haβler told me about his work on school-based teacher professional development and stressed how, by making open educational resources, teachers gain access to more high-quality teaching and learning resources and are empowered to take ownership of them and adapt them to their particular circumstances. Such open models radically reduce costs and have unprecedented scalability, and I believe that this House can learn from his work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, increasing resources for education is crucial, because that is the only way developing countries can really move towards economic growth. Of course, education is a passport to life in order to tackle poverty. We all agree that resources need to be increased. The question is how to implement it. Because the main issue is that resources very often exist but policies are not implemented properly, and we have examples of allocating funds to non-governmental organisations, which do not make the best use of the money they receive. I think that at this point we need to be much more decisive and, of course, to intensify controls. On the other hand, of course, strengthening education, and in particular higher education, is crucial for african countries. Only in this way can there be development so that the inhabitants of Africa remain in Africa and thus limit migration.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs and all the Members of the European Parliament who contributed to this report, which confirms once again the support of this Parliament for the education sector. We will, of course, take into account a number of recommendations put forward in this report. The right to quality education is a fundamental right for all. It constitutes an essential condition for the enjoyment of human rights and for the achievement of all the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Moreover, by investing in education, we fight poverty. Basic reading skills could take at least 170 million people out of global poverty.  The Commission agrees that education should remain at the core of our development cooperation, focusing on those most in need. The European Consensus on Development highlights the importance of education for promoting responsible citizenship, developing sustainable societies and boosting youth employment. Your report constitutes an opportunity to recall these objectives. It gives additional input and impetus to our common endeavour. As recently stated by the World Bank, the investments needed in human capital have become more important as the nature of work has evolved. The content of education programmes and the skills acquired by students have to be relevant to the needs of the current and future labour market.  In this context, the European Union will continue to support scholarships and exchange programmes between tertiary education institutions and build capacities and knowledge within universities through actions such as Erasmus+. As recently announced in our new Africa—Europe Alliance for Sustainable Investment and Jobs, by 2020 the European Union will have supported 35 000 African students and academics through the Erasmus Programme. By 2027, these figures should reach over 105 000.  In your report, you also underline the importance of gender equality and the inclusion of vulnerable children and of course, the Commission shares your view. These two elements must remain essential components of quality education, contributing to fulfilling the 2030 Agenda by leaving no one behind.  The Commission also welcomes your emphasis on education in times of emergencies and crisis. Ensuring continuing education for children and young people living in crisis situations is a pressing issue, particularly for girls. Already now, more than 60% of the European Union’s bilateral funding for education goes to countries affected by conflict and fragility. Furthermore, our humanitarian budget for education in emergencies has gone up from 1% in 2015 to 8% this year and 10% in 2019.  But of course we need further and more coordinated efforts, also with our international partners. For this reason, the Commission adopted its first ever policy framework on education in emergencies and crises in May 2018, a new major dimension of our actions. The Commission also welcomes the call in the report to involve all stakeholders in the dialogue at international and local level. Multilateral work is as important as bilateral country work. Currently the European Union supports 45 developing partner countries with bilateral education funding worth around EUR 3.4 billion. The European Union is also a major contributor to the Global Partnership for Education, which brings together all relevant actors to achieve the objective of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal to ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all.  Overall, the targets set out in your report are ambitious, but consistent with the international agenda and with the Commission approach. We very much look forward to continuing in the years to come our cooperation with Parliament in keeping quality and inclusive education high on the European Union’s development cooperation agenda.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I'm closing the agenda. The vote will take place on Tuesday 13 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Access to education is a challenge, especially for countries in the grip of war or conflict. In sub-Saharan Africa alone, 87 million primary-school-age children and adolescents were out of school in 2014, according to UNESCO, which noted in 2016 that "half of the out-of-school children and adolescents in conflict-affected countries in 2013 were in sub-Saharan Africa." The situation is thus particularly critical in some states such as the Democratic Republic of Congo, which has been plagued by latent conflicts. First of all, it is a humanitarian issue, listed as the fourth sustainable development objective. It is also a strategic issue, given Africa's tremendous growth potential. The development of primary and secondary education will thus be decisive to ensure, in the years to come, the maintenance or even the development of the French language on the continent. Initiatives such as the Ifadem (French-language initiative for distance training of masters), deployed under the aegis of the International Organization of the Francophonie, should therefore be welcomed. It is up to us that French becomes, by 2050, the first language of Africa.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. Education is not only a fundamental right but is also the key to development, as it plays an essential role as a multiplier for development itself. It implies an increase in skills and opportunities for individuals, generating a critical spirit and economic independence. Perhaps we underestimate the fact that millions of children in the world do not have access to education due to conflict, forced displacement and violence, because the real risk is that a whole generation will remain in a perennial state of need and dependence. That is why education must be at the heart of efforts to achieve the 2030 Agenda, simply because it is preparatory to achieving the other Sustainable Development Goals. In this respect, however, I would like to stress the need to ensure that development funds are genuinely allocated in a coherent manner and as a matter of priority to vocational education and training programmes. Development involves education, and I hope that this concept will be put into practice, including specific goals and objectives in the next Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, these days we are commemorating the 100th anniversary of the end of The First World War. We are reminded of this so that millions of deaths, millions of victims, are not forgotten and that we remind the young generation of the main reason why we have the European Union as an area of peace. In 1914, people also did not believe that there could be a war, in a time of rationality and progress. Monarchy families in Europe have been intertwined with kinship, and who wants to fight their own? But nationalism prevailed. In 1918, they were convinced that this war was the last, that nothing like this could happen again – and yet twenty years later. Today we live in a time of peace, but peace is not self-evident, and many young people tell me that they cannot imagine war, they are convinced that it is not possible. That is why it is necessary to commemorate the millions of the fallen in both world wars.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Creu, next week in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria , Canary Islands, which is my land – the summit of outermost regions will take place, with the presence of President Jean Claude Juncker. And outermost meetings are important for the countries in which they are framed: Spain, Portugal and France. But for the European Union, the outermost meetings are ultra-important, and I quote President Tajani of this Parliament, because they are an opportunity to verify the scope of Article 349 in the future of Europe, in the multiannual financial framework, in energy and neighbourhood policies, trans-European networks and, above all, employment. But it is also important to review the impact of Brexit on regions highly dependent on the massive flow of tourists, many of them from the UK. And finally, it is very important that the conquest of the future does not dilute, let alone destroy or reverse, the traditional policies of the European Union for the primary sector, which does not diminish POSEI, which is vital for this dimension of the primary sector in the economic field, in the ecological field and in the social field.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, yesterday the Albanian Government declared me persona non grata because I am defending the human rights of the Greek minority in the North Continent, which are being trampled on by the Albanian regime. The minority lives in a climate of terrorism and tacit ethnic cleansing. The demographic composition of the population in purely Greek areas changes dramatically with the transfer of settlers, the property rights of Greeks are violated by the state by intimidation and arbitrary and illegal acts, while their educational rights and the use of the Greek language are systematically persecuted. Not long ago, the Albanians murdered Aristotle Guma for speaking Greek. A few days ago Konstantinos Katsifas because he raised the Greek flag. I regret that the European Parliament did not want to discuss the violation of the human rights of the minority. I believe that it must immediately send an ad hoc committee to seek the truth about what is happening in the Greek community, without the presence of the regime's moles who terrorize the citizens.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for On my way here, I crossed a number of old national borders, reminding one of what we are trying to create on this continent since 1945: a Union without borders dedicated to peace and openness. Unfortunately, my own government has just recently chosen to go in completely the opposite direction. Sweden on Thursday renewed the maintenance of internal border controls. The reason given is internal security and concern about terrorism. However, the number of returning jihadists has fallen forcefully. The wave of refugees from 2015 is just a trickle. It can therefore be said that the measures are not aimed at preventing terrorism, but are aimed at reducing the influence of the extreme right by giving them messages of 'racism light'. The dream of 1945 is still possible. It is important to be reminded of this these days, when we remember how many people died in these battlefields on this continent. Functioning internal borders within the EU naturally presuppose the existence of functioning external borders. That dream, however, is possible, and we should go down that path.

name: Miroslavs MITROFANOVS
text: – Madam President, at the previous session of the European Parliament we adopted the resolution on the rise of neo—fascist violence in Europe. The overwhelming majority of the Members of Parliament voted in favour of this resolution. It was a clear signal to all Member States and the political forces: Europe is against politically—motivated violence and against the rise of neo—Nazist ideology. What happened then? In my country, in Latvia, the anti—fascist resolution was met either by ignorance or sharp criticism by ruling politicians and the mainstream media, and it is not an exception. All signals coming from the external world which do not fit the nationalistic ideology of the ruling parties are simply ignored by them and the Latvian—language media.  What is important from the point of view of the Latvian Russian minority, because of the ignorance and double standards applied by Latvian authorities also in the case when we need the State to react against hate speech, or the relentless persecution of national minorities – a majority against the minorities. There was no reaction after the Minister for Education asked Latvians to get rid of the empathy towards minorities. There was no reaction when we asked the police several times to investigate the hate speech by one Latvian intellectual who called the local Russians ‘genetic trash’. In these conditions, we ask the European Union to elaborate clear and strong rules for preventing hate speech on the level of national States.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, this day last week, John Downey was arrested in Ireland. The British government have publicly stated in a British court that John Downey was not wanted, and the court ruled to that effect. The European arrest warrant used against John Downey follows a campaign to introduce an amnesty for British state forces at a time when the spotlight is on them for their actions. John Downey is an Irish republican and a strong advocate of the peace process. His arrest gives lie to claims by Mrs Theresa May that the legacy process is skewed against former British state forces – a lie which was denounced by even the DPP and the PSNI. A lie feeding the British attempts to secure impunity and immunity for British state forces guilty of crimes in Ireland. A lie directly linked to a British government currently in hock to a party, the Democratic Unionist Party, whose leader, Arlene Foster, unlawfully blocked the funding requested for the Lord Chief Justice’s legacy plan. John Downey’s arrest was politically motivated.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, exactly fifteen years ago, on 12 November 2003, dozens of our dear carabinieri and other soldiers, two civilians and other people of foreign nationality died at the carabinieri base in Nassiriya. I wanted to remember these heroes, not least so that we never question the courage, the loyalty of our beloved carabinieri, especially when perhaps someone would like to speculate shamefully on isolated cases of behaviour far removed from this glorious story of dedication and fidelity to the institutions. A thought and a memory, of course also to their families, of this weapon of the carabinieri that is the mirror of Italy of the honest and the pride of all honest Italians.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Yesterday Poland celebrated the symbolic centenary of its independence. The problem is that this anniversary is a little unfortunate, because most of this period Poland was not really an independent country and today it is no longer the case today because of the signing of the Treaty of Lisbon. In 1918, we had to ask the Germans if we could declare independence, in 2018 we have to ask the Germans at what age Polish judges can retire, so if we ask ourselves who actually lost these two world wars, then first of all we are, as you can see, not Germany. The giggle of history is that the ruling party, which now often invokes such independence rhetoric, also against the Authorities of the European Union, in 2003, for EU money, took part in hysterical deceitful propaganda in favour of Polish joining the European Union. She signed, her president signed the Treaty of Lisbon, so they sold Polish independence for EU silver, and now they themselves face the consequences of it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, the Romanian government led by PSD-ALDE mocks the health of Romanians. Moreover, this irresponsible government deprives them of the right to life and health by constantly refusing to use European funds for investments in the health care system. Recently, he refused to use the 150 million euros made available by the European Commission for the construction of three regional emergency hospitals, namely Cluj, Iasi and Craiova. That's when the same government was demanding money in the same direction in 2015 under the regional operational programme. Thus, although the local authorities in Cluj, for example, have taken all necessary steps to start this investment, inexplicably, the PSD-ALDE government simply refuses European money, taking away romanians' chance to benefit from quality medical services. I publicly call on the Romanian government to use all the financial resources made available by the European Commission to increase the quality of the medical act and to save the lives of Romanians.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, in Bedfordshire, crime is reaching crisis point with four murders in Bedford and Luton in the last six months, while knife crime is up 86% since 2014. Demand for the police is at an all-time high, and officers are stretched to limit. Indeed, the Bedfordshire Chief Constable said he did not have enough officers to respond to 999 calls.  The problem is well documented. Bedfordshire police is underfunded. It is treated as a rural force, but has urban challenges. Bedfordshire has the third—highest terror risk in the country and a rapidly expanding international airport. A higher proportion of domestic abuse offences happen in the county than in places like Manchester, and 40% of all guns used illegally across my constituency are fired in Bedfordshire. And behind the statistics are people who live in fear, bigger insurance bills, and grieving families. So I wholeheartedly support the Times & Citizen campaign. It is time to fund our police properly.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, some time ago this House rejected my proposal and the ECR Group's proposal for a special debate on the murder of Konstantinos Katsifas by the Albanian police and to discuss, at the same time, the violation of the rights of the Greek ethnic minority in the North Continent. The plenary of the European Parliament 'threw the ball on the podium'. I don't think that's how it goes right. The killers of Konstantinos Katsifas must be revealed and I think eurojust, in cooperation with the Athens Public Prosecutor's Office, should examine who was the one who murdered Konstantinos Katsifas, because he was a Greek citizen; was a citizen of the European Union. Furthermore, the European Parliament, with a special committee, must examine the violation of the rights of the Greek minority in the North Continent, because all its rights are being violated. There's a real ethnic cleansing going on. Kosovars and settlers are transported in order to clear the area. At the same time, the message must be sent that Albania has no place in the European Union.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, Alcoa does not close. I want to support the struggle of Alcoa workers, for the worrying situation of the American multinational Alcoa, which announced the closure of its factories in A Coruña in Galicia and Avilez in Asturias, and which represents the loss of 700 direct jobs in the aluminum monopoly of the Spanish State. It is about closing a company, after receiving a large amount of public money, and the risks it poses to my country's industry having an invoice from the most expensive in Europe. A multinational cannot be allowed to increase its accounts through public money and then carry out a brutal destruction of employment. That is why we denounce this problem in this European Parliament, we sympathize with the workers and ask that the company not use the employment regulation procedure. Moreover, that it does not continue to circumvent the legislation and, as there is a monopoly, we ask for public intervention by the Spanish State, more than justified because it is a strategic undertaking. Alcoa doesn't close!

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Madam President, ArcelorMittal is buying italian smelters Ilva. The Acquisition was reviewed by the European Commission and ordered the company to sell some of its other plants. It decided to sell ostrava metallurgical plants, which employ over seven thousand people in my Moravian-Silesian region. The risk of closure of smelters for the region associated with the sale is enormous, as it is currently facing a downturn in coal mining and the insolvencies of many other companies, which have already lost thousands of jobs in recent years. All trade unions operating in ostrava smelters strongly object to the selection of liberty steel buyers. Their main arguments are violations of the terms of sale under European legislation concerning the obligation for the buyer to have financial resources, proven knowledge in the field and an incentive to develop the company sold as a viable competitive force. If, as the Commission, you have said that you want to intervene in this sale in some way, please do not bankrupt part of my republic, part of my region, just because we are going to sell it to someone who just can't do it and does nothing about it.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, just one hundred years ago, on 11 November 1918, the First World War came to an end. We must commemorate this great victory of France and its allies for which 1.4 million French soldiers gave their lives. A delegation from the ENL group commemorated it on the battlefield of Verdun where 163,000 French people died blocking the passage to the invader. I want to forcefully recall my truth about this terrible war which is not the pseudo-truth peddled by President Macron. It was not the nationalism of the French fighters and their allies that provoked the war, but the imperialism of the German Reich. These are empires that provoked both world wars and nations that defended their freedom and the freedom of the world. Let the European Union not forget it, it dreams of turning into a new empire. Imperialism is war; nationalism is the engine of peoples' right to self-determination.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Madam President, in August I contacted the Council asking for two documents to be made available. One of them was the forthcoming draft EU guidelines on human rights on non-discrimination in external action. Last week, after two months, my request by the Council was officially rejected. The reasoning for refusing to provide the Member of the European Parliament with guidance to be followed by the staff of the European External Service states that this would expose delegations to undue pressure from the parties concerned. Members of this House must be informed about how the principles of the functioning of EU representations in the world are being created. Anyone who regards the interest of a Member as undue pressure disdains parliamentaryism and mocks all of us. I ask that the President of Parliament act with all determination.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Madam President, colleagues, the resolution on Romania is a great injustice for a deeply European country, which respects the principles of the rule of law, European democratic values, as well as the Constitution of the State and the decisions of the European Court. In fact, in Romania the government and the parliamentary majority are doing nothing but huge efforts to ensure a reform of the justice system, precisely in the sense of respect for civil rights and freedoms, the presumption of innocence and the opportunity for a just and fair trial, without televised justice or interference from the secret services. I note, however, with regret that some European leaders are sacrificing Romania on the altar of political interests generated by the upcoming European Parliament elections, without realizing that such games are merely divided the Union. The same leaders do not realise that these actions pose a great danger to the future of the European Union, for power lies in unity and solidarity, not in the condemnation and discrimination of the Member States. That is why I ask my Romanian colleagues, at least in the twelfth hour, to make a gesture of dignity and not to vote for this resolution, and for all Members of the European Parliament to give a "no" vote, because this resolution and such political games only deepen the gap between eastern and western Europe.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, we are clearly seeing that Spanish justice has a problem. One of the pillars of any democracy, a properly functioning and trustworthy judicial system, is reeling right now in the Spanish state.  This is demonstrated to us by the European Court of Human Rights every time it condemns Spain for violating fundamental rights. Last week the Spanish Supreme Court itself demonstrated this to us, scandalously contradicting its own judgments, which are theoretically firm, when it ended up giving reason to the banks and ruled that it was the client who had to continue to pay the mortgage tax, and we are shown cases such as Alsasua's, La Manada's and so many others.  In relation to the process against Catalan democratic independence, looking at this background, seeing the instruction that has been going on so far, seeing the fables that appear in the court proceedings on violence, rebellion, being treated as a political trial, can anyone trust that Catalan political prisoners will have a fair trial? Not us.  The Spanish judicial system has a problem and the European Union should be concerned.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, the shipyards of La Naval Sestao, in Biscay, are the only ones that have held open to date among all the shipyards that were privatized last decade. Your workforce has decades of experience. They have built the world's largest dredgers or high-tech gas companies. But now they're threatening to close them. The reality of its region, Ezkerraldea, an area that receives ERDF funds for high unemployment rates, is also worrying. The closure of a company that can generate up to four thousand jobs between direct and indirect will undoubtedly have a devastating effect. It will be of little use if the administrations stand by in the face of this threat of closure. Regaining the presence of the public shareholding within the strategic sectors is today the best recipe that can be taken. And not only is it the best, but it's also possible. Public entry into La Naval is possible within the Rules of the European Union themselves. It is therefore time for the Government of Spain and the Basque Government to stop looking the other way, stop seaing and give a future to both La Naval and the ezkerraldea region.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to make a point that I consider to be really dangerous for our future, and that is the issue of pesticides and their use. Pesticides are useful servants, but at the same time they can be very harmful masters if they get out of real control. A significant reduction in pesticide use within half a kilometre of schools and nurseries is already under discussion in California. Currently, there are several studies that indicate the effect of pesticides as harmful not only to the development of children, but also to the development of the fetus itself. For future regulation, it is therefore recommended to include pregnant women. Although more research is needed, these initial studies could be alarming for us. Pesticides affect autism spectrum disorder, also the incidence of ADHD and increase the risk of developing Parkinson's disease. Let us therefore create a truly responsible policy for the future. Pesticides may be useful, but usefulness cannot be put above a healthy developing society. Moreover, we will have the opportunity to show what we mean about pesticides on our European continent in the coming days, because the relevant report is already being discussed in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Madam President, the Conservative Party continues down a path that experts have warned will spell disaster. For once, I’m not talking about Brexit, I’m talking about fracking. The government’s own studies show that fracking will increase air pollution. The British Geological Service say that water supplies could be contaminated. There have been 37 earthquakes since drilling began at Preston New Road in Lancashire: and what benefit is there to local people? A measly 11 jobs will be created. We don’t fracking in Lancashire. The community has said no to fracking; local politicians have said no to fracking; the Labour Party has said no to fracking. It’s hard to imagine the Conservatives doing this in their communities in the Surrey heartlands, but they are running roughshod over the north west of England. It cannot continue. I am proud that Labour MEPs have consistently supported ambitious EU proposals that put the protection of our environment first. And to the communities of Lancashire who feel left behind by the Conservatives, I can tell you now: Labour stands with you and with all those standing against fracking in Lancashire and around Europe.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, last October Julián Carrillo, indigenous leader, Gabriel Soriano Kuri, journalist, and Noel Castillo Aguilar, defender of indigenous rights, were killed in Mexico.  According to the United Nations, only ten journalists and twelve defenders have been killed in Mexico in 2018.  The renewal of the Comprehensive Agreement between the European Union and Mexico is about to be concluded, but it is essential that a democratic clause linking us all appears there. There must be no unethical business.  It is therefore important that the democratic clause has guarantees, can be controlled, revised, denounced for non-compliance by civil organizations and indigenous defenders of the Earth and the environment.  The hope that comes to us with the election of President López Obrador must be realized in a strong, rigorous text, a real defender of democracy and justice for Mexico and for the European Union. The opposite would be a terrible and incomprehensible disappointment.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, there has been lots of talk about the rise of right—wing populism and how the Centre must hold in next year’s elections. Well, last month, Ireland had its first test of right—wing politics, and while the vast majority of the electorate rejected it, we cannot ignore that 23.1% chose to vote for a candidate that preached division. This time, it wasn’t anti-refugee or anti-Islam, but instead he chose to target the traveller community and those on social welfare.  Those of us who believe in equality must stand up and make our voices heard in rejecting the politics of hate and fear, and we must call it out wherever it manifest itself. But we must also address the root causes of discontent among those who vote for such candidates. Lack of housing, insecure work, and the politics of pitting one group of individuals against another are simply the outworkings of the neoliberal economic model loved by the so-called ‘centrist’ parties in this House. If we really want to defeat right—wing populism, then we must defeat centrist politics.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – At our last plenary session, the President of the European Commission spoke of the fact that it is also a celebration of Europe on the occasion of romania's upcoming national day. I would like that to be the case, but to do that, we need to look at exactly what the 100th anniversary of will be on 1 December. The Declaration of Gyulafehérvár, in which the need to annex Transylvania to Romania was stated, but in which a number of important promises were made, such as that the various peoples living in Transylvania would be granted full national freedom and that, and that , and I quote, "individuals from each people's bosom" would use public education in their own language with public administration and justice. In fact, this means territorial autonomy in szeklerland, which is inhabited mostly by Hungarians, and personal autonomy for minorities in Transylvania and other parts, including Hungarians.  These promises have not been fulfilled by the Romanian State, so we can celebrate the centenary of the declaration when they are implemented. Mr Juncker also made reference to the Saxons living in Transylvania: the fact that only a few thousand of the German minority of more than half a million people remained in Transylvania 100 years ago is regrettable and ponderable.

name: Giuseppe FERRANDINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the last ten days, 37 people have died in Italy as a result of floods. In the same hours, the government included measures in the Genoa decree for the areas affected by the latest seismic events, instead of seriously legislating on reconstruction. Because reconstruction means that the State assists its citizens, in full compliance with Italian and Community rules, individual and safe, and ensures a home for those who have lost it, without getting lost in quibbles and bureaucracy.  From the government, on the other hand, only hypotheses of sanatoria have arrived that do not help those who have lost their homes, but generate only false expectations because they lengthen the time without offering a solution. Approaching such a complicated issue so superficially, just to maximise the outcome at the next European elections, is a defeat for politics and for the citizens. But there are far worse aspects to this. The Italian Government has rejected a loan of as much as 800 million from the EIB for hydrogeological risk mitigation. It is clear that there is a lack of foresight in this choice, while we are calling for the funds for these important and vital projects to be excluded from budgetary constraints.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Madam President, Romania is a European state with European values, whose people were most enthusiastic about the news of accession among all the peoples of the Member States that were welcomed into the great European family after 1990. In 2007 Romanians overwhelmingly expressed their confidence in the European Union in a percentage exceeding 65%. I call on all fellow MEPs to make an effort to understand these things before tomorrow's vote. Any vote against Romania will set a dangerous precedent for any Member State and separate western and eastern Europe. The resolution on Romania shows that many of the colleagues who will vote in favour of it did not understand that Romania is a rule of law, with pro-European values, in which the Constitution, the laws of the country and the will of the people take precedence. This resolution demonstrates that many European colleagues did not understand that Romanians have the right to express their will in a referendum, whether the result of which we like it or not, and that Romanian citizens have exactly the same rights and privileges as any other European citizen. Please, Madam President, please, ladies and gentlemen, think tomorrow before you vote on the resolution for Romania.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Romania has proved to be an honest partner of the European Union and a country that has not strayed from its European path. Nothing is now different from this point of view. Romanian citizens are unqualified supporters of the European project, the Romanian government has shown openness to the European Parliament and to all European institutions and this must be appreciated. That is why I believe that the agenda of some politicians or political groups should not also build the agenda of the European Parliament. The discussions in Romania concern only internal political issues and, as such, cannot accept biased opinions, such as those of right-wing leaders. I call on my fellow MEPs to be fair to Romania in tomorrow's vote on a resolution that is an unjustified action and to treat it wisely, not in a political or electoral key. The European Union needs solidarity, and this can only be achieved if we are guided by fairness in decisions concerning the Member States.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, I’m not sure there’s ever been a time in my lifetime when there’s been a greater need for free, independent journalism. But this is also a time when we see journalists facing persecution and violence here in the European Union and across the world. The Nottingham branch of the National Union of Journalists have recently written to me to raise their concerns about the persecution of journalists – their colleagues – across the world. I know those concerns will be shared by journalists, unions and federations across Europe and indeed across the world, and they have my solidarity. We need journalists to help speak truth to power and to help ask the difficult questions. Every journalist everywhere must be able to go about their work free of harassment, intimidation, bullying and violence. That’s a right that we in this European Parliament and in the European Union must ensure is upheld everywhere.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, traditional parties in Europe are being defeated in the recent elections. Why? I dare say that the problem is not in the economic situation and not even in the refugee crisis, but in the rapid decline in the significance of Europe in the world. The population of Greater Europe at the beginning of the 20th century was one—third of the world population. Now the share has dropped to 12%, and by 2050 the Europeans will be only 7% of the world’s population. The share of the EU economy by 2050 will be reduced from the current 15% to 9% of the global economy. Visible changes have already occurred, but not only have they become visible to society, but the loss of significance of Europe leads to the loss of many past advantages, and people feel that. This is not a reason for fear and panic, but a reason for honest re—thinking. Then there will be less surprises and more useful solutions for our citizens.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
